reviewText:
The Game itself is ok, but I found it buggy. This wouldn't be so much of a problem if it had acceptable customer service, which it doesn't. Perfect World's Customer service does nothing for you, except have you jump through hoops, and give you cookie cutter responses. I played the game a year or so ago, and left because the customer service was lacking.

I came back to the game a few weeks ago (to discover my old toons, were wiped away, but thats not my complaint)
Due to a bug, I lost access to the captain level ships. The GM I contacted was unable or unwilling to do anything to address the issue other than telling me that it would take development time to fix the issue, and then told me to submit a bug report, but that QA wouldn't repond to me. After leveling for several weeks, I found my character unable to proceed with the game, and I couldn't bring myself to continue playing and supporting a company that treats its customers in such a way.

There are plenty of other games out there, from companies who know what customer service is supposed to be. I will never play another game with perfect world's name attached to it.

reviewText:
Since Star Trek Online is now free to play, there is no real reason to buy it other than to save yourself a 4 GB download. This is a massive multiplayer online game that is part role playing game, part over the shoulder shooter and part star ship navigation and combat. I love Star Trek as we probably all do to even be here reading this. I've always wanted a game that gives you the total feeling of captaining a star ship, commanding an away team and interacting in a universe. Star Trek online feels shallow and hollow in some areas, yet needlessly cumbersome in others.

The game is shallow with interactions and choices. The game delegates talking with characters down to a portrait and written text. No voice acting, but maybe I have been spoiled. I take that back, there is some horrible voice acting from Leonard Nemoy to start the game and the holographic doctor that acts as a tutorial is one of the flattest and worst voice acting I've ever heard. Especially when the EMH doctor on Star Trek Voyager uses the same lines with a pop and snap. The dialog is so bland that I just skip through it because everything you need to do is marked with an exclamation point. It would have also felt better to be able to interact with more random objects like scan flowers that are not marked and have a 1% chance every hour to find something. There are still interactions like anomalous readings that open up a wave pattern mini game that is very easy to say the least.

Right off the bat it is a disappointment as you are thrown into a conflict with the Borg who in the Star Trek universe should not be for beginners. Nor should they fall easily, but you might as well have a fly swatter for all the Borg you'll encounter.

Luckily if you have a problem with the missions, there is an actual mission editor. You can submit your missions and have them put into the game which is a nice touch.

Like any MMO, you get to pick a race, pick a class from three (red, blue and yellow). Everyone seems to pick red. Each race has special traits and you can customize your look with excessive detail. It all feels very superficial.

When you're not walking around and talking, you're either flying a ship or shooting things. The shooting is good and pretty easy even if its one dimensional. Point your phaser at the target you want to die or blow up and keep firing til its dead. Shooting civilians doesn't matter... and it should. You get an away party that you make up of crew members that you find or recruit throughout your play. Its a fun micromanagement thing and your allies are pretty competition and takes away from a MMO when your party is made of computer characters. The ability to just jump into someone else's party to replace the computer would have been nice.

You have some basic controls to fly around, but it seems a little cumbersome, throttling up to go forward and then going to impulse... Flying around objects and toward objects to blow them up or beam off survivors. The visuals are beautiful here, but the fact you're over dead space makes things seem pretty lifeless unless there's a space battle going on.

Space battles are where the game excels. You have 4 power" settings... attack

reviewText:
First of all: If you like Star Trek and think flying your own starship would be awesome, this is a good game for you.

Personally, I like this game. I know plenty of people who will say it's crap, the devs are awful, the game's engine is bad, and so on and so forth. The graphics are good enough, there's not much lag, and it's generally fun to blow up Borg. Coming from a few other F2P games (*cough* WAR THUNDER *cough*), I feel as though the developers of STO do somewhat care about their playerbase.

Game progression is easy enough, until you hit level 50. Leveling up to 60 gets a bit tedious, but you can access the whole game (minus a few not-really-important story missions) from 50. The learning curve is fairly steep - I'd recommend looking at a few tutorials before trying to work in the community exchange. There is, as always, premium currency, but you can change one of the other types of currency into it (for a large ingame expense). There are multiplayer missions with other players, and the harder the difficulty the better the rewards are upon completion. There are eight or so campaigns" that give out some good gear. The ships are accurate

reviewText:
If you like star trek and MMORPG, definetely try out this game.

If you like star trek but not MMORPG, well, have a try. At least the storyline will satisfy you.

If you like MMORPG but not star trek, why not check this game out? It's a good MMORPG.

If you hate both, don't play this game then. You can't have fun, why playing it?

I just hit 1k hours. The storyline of this game will MAKE YOU CHEER when you see characters you love from Star Trek appearing. The space combat is awesome. The ground combat is not as popular among players as space combat but also very nice.

You can enjoy this game the best when you play with your friends, but I have to say that in-game chatting is LAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAME!! If you want to chat well, you'll have to rely on some other aps.

This game has its disadvantages though. First, the endgame period, like many other RPGs, are boring. All you can do is repeating some missions every day. This is not true when you are chasing for higher stats and competing with other players.

For me, all the weaknesses don't matter because I LOVE THIS GAME.

The fact that you can get a huge capital ship by simply getting to the endgame and not needing to pay for one was a great surprise. The seasonal events were a blast. Definitely give it a shot if you are an mmo or startrek fan.

reviewText: Absolutely fantastic game. I've played for years and yes, sometimes the content in the new seasons leaves something to be desired, and the cost for zen-store content is a bit on the greedy side, but for a free-to-play title I'm happy to tithe forward a few bucks every month for a few extra nice-to-have cosmetic goodies. The foundry (permitting self-written content) is fantastic. The replayability is high and frankly - being able to pop online and fly a ship around the Star Trek universe for a bit provides a nice break from the daily grind. NOT a game for those who want PVP - but since I'm happily well in the PVE preferring body of gamers I've got zero issues with that. There are some variances from Star Trek canon, but the development team at PW seems to have continued to work on keeping to what's reasonable for the universe as Roddenberry framed it. The variety of story lines can sometimes come across as a mash-up that doesn't mesh terribly well, but the quantity and variety vastly outweigh any annoyance at those moments. Highly recommend giving it a go - as a f2p option you've literally got nothing but some time to lose and the chance to get to know a hell of a good game.

reviewText:
Mostly for Star Trek fans, but if you are a Trekkie and are willing to invest into a MMO timesink this is for you.

One of the few truly F2P games. No game content is behind paywalls. Only premium equipment requires in-game purchases and even those can be grinded for free given enough time. In-game currency Dilithium can be converted into Zen which is used for purchases. Exchange rate at this time is about 1:200 (zen to dil, most premium ships cost 2500-3000 zen, which is about 20$ real money) and there is a daily refining limit of 8000 dilithium. So it takes a while, but can be done. Gets easier if you have several characters grinding dilithium as Zen pool is account wide. So Pay-to-Bypass-Grind is more accurate for this game.

Only veteran awards require montly subscription (or Lifetime account) but those are mostly cosmetic upgrades and one endgame level ship. Only truly worthy perk is the 500 Zen montly stipend.

As far as game mechanics go, this is an MMO like any other. Gather experience, level up, grind for gear, team up, form guilds (Fleets). Both ground and space combat are in the game, though the ground side isn't as interesting. It is the space combat which makes this game a little different from other MMO's. Much like SWToR, the single player missions, or Episodes, are the bread&butter for Star Trek fans. Featuring voice over acting from actual Star Trek actors, like the late Leonard Nimoy, one could not ask for more story wise. Especially the newer content is very well written, and every now and then older content gets revised, the latest 'update' being mid-gameish Romulan story arc, which is now much more story-like as opposed to being just a bunch of missions in sequence. Also features Denise Crosby as Romulan Empress Sela.

Most of the game content is PvE. PvP exist, but hasn't been properly balanced or developed in years so not many people play it seriously. So hard-core PvPr's steer clear.

reviewText:
As much as I wish I could say otherwise, I cannot in good faith recommend Star Trek Online.

Star Trek Online isn't an MMO. It's a Star Trek themed resource management game with queue based resource gathering missions in-between filling up a dozen progress bars for things you don't even want or need. Your personalized crew that is so plastered over advertisements are nothing more than bland paper dolls with barely any customization options. They are so hardly ever used in the game they might as well not even exist.

Thinking you might at least be able to walk around the inside of your ship? Guess again. Outside of your bridge, ship interiors don't exist. It's not like there's any reason to visit it anyway. Everything is queue based.

Two years ago there wasn't a single thing about this game that was pay to win. Well it is now. The best ships and gear are locked behind so many resource gates you may as well pay out your nose and skip them or else you'll be grinding for hours.

Every system in the game, everything from Crafting, to the ships themselves seems specifically designed to bleed as much money out of you as physically possible. I realize that developers have to eat, but not only do you have to buy a ship, you have to essentially buy it twice to make it powerful enough to do anything.

I could give a dozen more reasons why this game isn't worth your time. I will simply say it isn't. Whether you are an old veteran wondering about coming back, or someone who hasn't played at all and is curious, from me, who has spend hundreds of dollars and hours on this game, I am telling you to love yourself.

And play something else.

reviewText:
I've been playing this game for several years now and it's definitely a wonderful game for all Star Trek fans old and new. I've always wanted to be the captain of my own ship and Star Trek Online gives you the chance to throw in your own character into the Star Trek universe with ease. The story line never gets old and they have recently added so much to the game to make the story line even longer. Levelling up alone is quite easy, but trust me, it's much better with a friend.

There are endless possibilities on what you can do in Star Trek Online. You can queue up in special missions to fight lots of dangerous species such as the Borg, Undine and now the Iconians. You can even just explore strange new worlds and beam down to millions of beautiful planets and even throw a beach party on Risa!

To be honest you don't even really have to be a major Trek fan to enjoy and like this game and you can learn so much about the Star Trek Universe just by playing the game. So if you're thinking of getting into Star Trek in an interactive way instead of watching seasons and seasons of the show this game is a good way to get yourself started.

The new reputation system is very long and requires a lot of grinding but at least you can do different things to gain marks. My favourite places to gain marks are New Romulus, the Dyson Sphere Ground Battlezone and Kobali Prime as you can really engage yourself in many different things such as missions or just shooting all the enemies you can see. Also the new system is a much better way for every one to be able to get the items as the old system was just pot luck and this caused a lot of elitists" to appear in game and this made things harder and more challenging for new players. Whereas now almost everyone can get the items easily and work better together as a team.

And
recommended: sometimes the game is laggy. But trust me I've played games with worser lag than on Star Trek Online. At least in this game it is sorted out by the creators instead of just being left there.\n\nIf you want to explore strange new worlds
hoursPlayed: seek out new civilizations and boldly go where no man has gone before. Then Star Trek Online is the game for you."

reviewText: The greatest MMO experience I've ever had. I made it all the way to 50 without paying a dime and without feeling underpowered (I met some very generous folks along the way that gave me abosolutely essential tips). The community is the most generous and helpful I've ever experienced, and more oftne than not when you want to sell or buy, you'll get a fair deal. The gameplay is so grabbing, you'll never notice the grind. I actually hit level 50 with only finishing the first 3 missions, the game is just THAT fun to play. I finally did go back, and I discovered a great story, and some great levelled loot that made me greatful I waited until level 50 to pick up. I can't recommend this game more, so in appreciation of how much gameplay I got out of  this title I spent $30 and grabbed a nice Tier 5 ship, upgraded it to T5U, picked up a few Duty Officers, bought some custom skins, eventually ended up spending about $60 total, becasue I felt that this game was worth a full release title's price. Get it, and lose your functioning social life!

reviewText:
As a lifetime account owner and playing through to Vice admiral back in the day. I can say this game no matter what they do to the interface and skill trees, is packed FULL of content. The dev team are very good with new content coming out all the time. For anyone who is a Star Trek Fan You cant go wrong with this. Its a Fantastic game for the price of £0 you dont need to pay to win. It Helps sure but you have a huge variety of ships and their classes.

There is one massive oversight. For me this is an immersion breaker. Its your bridge. The Bridge is instanced and is not relative to what you are doing in space at the time. Some functionality makes it useful but it absolutely sucks that you cant manage battles from your captains chair and no on screen" functionality.

Dont let this put you off. There is so much content youll be playing non stop for a year before you run out of interesting things to do. Many wierd and wonderful locations to explore both planet side and in space.

The Game itself is VISUALLY STUNNING and character creation is a great feature. Personally i think Escort Ships are the best way to have fun in battle as you can get more manouverability
date: that way it doesnt matter that they have less console slots as you go in guns forward and manage your shield one way until you absolutely need to manage left right and rear.\n\nMost gaming rigs with 2gb of video memory can run this at Max settings. Or very close to it."

reviewText:
STAR TREK: ONLINE  - 8/10-

Have Played for just under 18 hrs, loving it so far. its slightly like playing an offline version of EVE online (focus of both games are different). it has a compelling player Story; you leave your ship; you pick up and personalise crew; which go into combat with you on ground misssions; and assist in space warfare (which is my fav part of game BTW). Overall i've been impressed by the game especially since reading some of the bad reviews.  If you've been watching Star trek lately and are in the mood for some deep space exploration yourself. Give it a shot. I'll summersize the game's good and bad points, baring in mind i have only 17.7 Hrs logged into it so far.

GOOD POINTS:
. Space combat:
customising and naming one of many diff ship types (that youll gain access to later on), and sending them into space to blow ♥♥♥♥ up is REALLY fun!

. Instanced missions:
everything in the story is instanced, you feel like its YOUR story, there are no pugs hanging out in the BG messing with your immersion.

. Awesome story:
The games focus and rightly so! I've started as a romulan, and have been (so far) mainly doing story missions they have been well scripted, the parts that were voiced were ok/good. The content of the missions has been interesting (mainly becasue i get to blow a lot of things up in my ship) but also becasue the missions have weight and consequence. I was establishing homeworlds, negoticiating peace talks. The missions that did involve combat (most/all) elements all had meaning behind them. It definately wasnt a trashy roller coaster kill 100 sheep and report back system >=( so it has that going for it too!

. In-depth Character customisation:
Wont find many if any games that offer a better level of character customisation. you can literally create a new alien race that is playable on all three factions if you want to.

BAD POINTS:
. Takes a while to get the bigger and better ships.
. When aquring/buying new ships, a lot of them have cash shop upgraded versions with extra station slots and in some cases exrtra weapon slots. (wont matter in cluster ♥♥♥♥ PVP much) but is still kinda pay-to-win-BS. As i wont be doing much PVP myself im not too bothered.
.Graphics are kinda poor, On Max it delivers all it needs to, the explosions look really nice and the ship weapons are pew-pewey enough, they pass but it would be nice if they were closer to E.V.E's standards.
. U.I is kinda ugly, and sometimes confsuing (action bars'n'stuff)
. Warping. Costs a lot for new players to warp, so dont bother. (thankfully missions so far have been close enough) dont have to wait as long as E.V.E typically to arrive at new sectors.

I'm having a lot of fun, i was expecting a terrible game and what i found was actually something very promosing. it wont blow you away, but you should have a nice experience early on anyway.

reviewText:
I love this game. I have about 450 hours logged through Arc and still enjoy playing this game. It does have its flaws though. PVP is dead. The balancing for it was so bad that even the Devs admitted that it isn't what they wanted for it, but only have vague ideas on how to fix it with no immediate plans to make changes. Also the cost of the fancy ships are a bit ridiculous. You could pay the price of an entire game for how much you can spend on one measly ship.

That being said, you absolutely don't need to drop a single red cent to play this game all the way to the end without trouble. I never have and enjoy all the end-game PvE queues and battlezones. Seasonal events give free players the opportunity to have end-game ships with a bit of grinding.

Honestly, I feel like many Star Trek fans are just some of the hardest to please people on the planet. The game is hardly perfect but I find it enjoyable overall.

reviewText:
Star Trek Online is by far one of the best MMOs that I have played.
Personally, I'll try out an MMO for a couple hours, maybe play here and there later, and then uninstall because I've lost interest. But not this.

Cryptic has done a great job in developing this game. There are a few bugs here and there, but nothing too game-breaking. The story is very well done and is the part that keeps my attention. The leveling is also stellar, in most MMOs you'll sit there for hours and hours grinding to get to the next level. Or it sets you on a quest and the area is for level 20+ and you're level 10, you'll have to grind for days just to get to progress the story. Not with STO.

Each mission in STO does require you to be a certain level, BUT each mission also levels you up just enough to get to the next. And with the DOFF system (which is very easy to get the hang of) is an easy way of getting XP. I've known a few players who have gotten some of their characters to max level and not even leaving their faction's homeworld by using the DOFFs. The story is also interesting to say the least, it wasn't so good that I couldn't keep it off my mind, but it was good enough to keep coming back.

TL:DR The story is great, the developers are cool, and the leveling is stellar.
9/10

reviewText:
I decided to play this game on a whim awhile back. I tried to play this game before about a year or two ago and it was just a  screwed up cluster of junk on my screen. Now that I have come back and tried to play it again, it seems that a lot has been changed for the better in my opinion.

The grind wasn't that bad at all. I never found myself having to grind because of being underleveled and whatnot. By playing the episodes and playing on the event weekends (2x weekends, etc), I easily made it to Lv 55 in about 100 hours. Keep in mind that I casually played this game for about 2 - 3 hours a day.

The only thing I bought was 2k Zen, so I could buy my favorite ship, the Excelsior Refit Class. I was Lv 50 when I bought it. I could have gone with a T6 ship, but I already had the free Kobali Cruiser and I prefer the Excelsior Refit due to it's dashing good looks.

If there is one big problem with the game, it would be the ground missions. The ground mechanics are extremely boring. They really should focus on just scrapping the current ground system and re-building it with a more dynamic/controllable.

reviewText: The older this game gets the further it evolves away from the guiding principles of Star Trek. Where people don't work to get rich but to better themselves. Where exploration is the main goal. This game is getting more and more battle oriented and is all about getting currency. Be it Energy Credits, Dilithium, Lobi Crystals, Marks, various Commodities and Resources. Not counting the pay to win part where you have to spend real money to but ships and gear. The two faction Federation and Klingon uses ships from all kinds of species in their fleets, except each others. Be it Hirogen, Kazon, Undine, Ferengi or Cardassian. There is a semi-faction for the Romulans but they have been forced to be part of either the Federation or Klingon fleets. All the game is about now is grinding.

reviewText:
Don't let the low play time irritate you guys. I played this game almost from release and only a week before I finally quit it (Dec 2014) for good I added it to steam so I don't have to Alt-Tab every time someone texts me.

It used to be the best game ever in the entire universe. Everybody who played during the first couple seasons will agree with that.

Then PWE took over and thrashed it.

From what I hear there is no end to this agony, so I decided to stick the boot right in and write a review myself. Not being a man of many words, there is not much else to add. People who played and especially PVPed in this game exactly know why I and many many other started quitting the game after PWE took over.

If you never played STO before, then there is only one advice I can give you: run, run as fast and as far as you possibly can away from this game.

Its business model is following: everything is for free and you can obtain literally every single item in this game without spending a single Dollar, Euro, Pound, Banana or whichever is your country's currency. Sounds great, right? It is in fact great if you have a lifetime to wait for crafting and reputation missoins while you endlessly grind for dilithium. Of course you can accelerate this process by shoving your real world money up PWE's rear exit. We are not talking 2 Dollar microtransactions, no my friends, we are talking big money here.

If you even dream of being something remotely close to competitive in this game then you already play it for at least 2 years and know exactly what you're doing, or you have thousands of Dollars, Euros etc ready to be thrown at PWE.

To people who love and enjoy at least decent PVP matches: According to PWE's PR person The PVP community consists of 14 year olds living in their mum's basement". And that's also pretty much how PWE treats PVP in this game. The Queues may pop but what you find there is P2W spam deluxe.


Final verdict: Would not even force my special friend Geko to play it
date: that's how bad it is now."

reviewText:
This game (whilst with its flaws) is what i can honestly say to be one of my all time favorite ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes to date. I have yet to find an MMO with the atmosphere of satisfaction and wonder this one does. It is a true follow on to the overall Star Trek franchise and can be said as one of the most cannon Star Trek workings to keep ticking on with the true feeling and fantasy sci-fi kept within.
At a performance standar the game is prety easy and fun to control leaving the payer with the option tho change his/her controls if the have an significant problrms with it.The gameplay is pretty fun too. It is always improving with the game itself allowing the constant expansion of the franchise's own universe involving the timeline (25th Century) so that you can't simply say that youve already seen it or that its all been done before. Another thing i like is that the nature of the game features seasonal events than will constantly bring in new gameplay and all new missions and storyline to enjoy.
However, there are some issues i have with it. Mainly being that in order to advance thouroughly through the ranks and continue with certain missions and aspects, you are almost required to have 4 other consecuative friends to join you just so that you can make a fleet. Now i know thats just what MMORPG's tend to do but this slight detail means that I have to a)Continue the game with that ship I have owned for around 2 months or b)I simply join some other random clan in which would require me to talk to other people. I know shocking but considering that i dont have enough time to participate in the constant flow of events they would be asking me to join i would rather not.
Regardless, over all an enjoyable fun game that i can always rely upon for some relaxation and enjoyment if required

Personal Rating: 9/10

reviewText:
Reviewing Star Trek Online is an interesting experience, because it's a little hard to put my finger on why I play it sometimes.

Let's start with the basics: it's an MMORPG.  In a lot of ways, it's a very conventional RPG; a levelling system, more grind than a flour mill, regular bug-filled updates (which, to be fair, get fixed pretty quickly - the big, noticeable ones, at least).  It's also got two and a half factions which don't like each other, and since it's F2P, it's loaded with microtransactions.

It marks itself out with having both space and ground mechanics, being almost entirely instanced, and through being Star Trek.  Let's face it, if you're here, you're almost certainly a Trekkie to begin with.

The cons:
1. 'Micro'transactions.  This game is not cheap.  I've played over 400 hours and not bought anything from the C-store, and I don't feel particularly helpless, but endgame ships will set you back around $40.  Admittedly that's a one-off payment, and any future characters can use that ship without restriction, but it's still a fairly large investment.
2. Endgame balance is horrible.  The Special Task Force missions (read: raids) have almost dead public queues due to horrific imbalance in capability between a newly minted Lvl 60 player and an experienced and well-equipped endgame player; we're talking not a difference of 25% or so, but in the order of 1000% or more.  This has a few nasty side-effects for obtaining important gear; not insurmountable, but certainly frustrating.
3. Complexity curve.  The game itself is relatively simple, but there are a lot of behind-the-scenes mechanics that are not even slightly self-evident.  These aren't a big obstacle to gameplay until lvl 50 or so, but it can make the experience feel sluggish and frustrating.  Browsing of the STO reddit is highly recommended if you want to stick with the game.
4. Ground combat is subpar.  I personally don't think it's as bad as some people make out, but it's not nearly as fun as space stuff.  There are a few exceptions (personal cloaking devices combined with plasma flamethrowers are immensely entertaining) but it just doesn't feel as polished and developed.  Fortunately it's also a lot more forgiving in general.

With that in mind, let's get to the reason why I keep coming back to this thing.

1. Space combat is excellent.  Once you get used to the interface (I know some people find it awkward) it's very fluid.  As a long-time Eve Online player, I can honestly say that I prefer the STO mechanics; managing flight controls, a wide variety of offensive and defensive powers, and wrestling with keeping the enemy lined up with your weapons while keeping your shields boosted is a wonderful challenge.  It's also pretty as sin and really feels like Star Trek.  Diving at a Borg cube as the Defiant with all cannons blazing or seeing phaser fire bloom off your Galaxy as you maneuver at a stately pace around a hostile D'deridex is a great feeling.  Some of the powers also really give a suitably epic feel.  Using Torpedo Spread engulfs entire enemy squadrons in fields of photon torpedoes, while Fire At Will will make every beam you have fire at every enemy in range.
2. Flexibility.  When making a character, you pick faction (Federation, Klingon or Romulan) and a 'class'; Tactical, Science or Engineering.  In World of Warcraft, that would be it: you'd have just picked your playstyle for the rest of the game.  Not so here; your class only governs a set of basic powers you have, and what powers you can use in ground combat.  You still have the full range of ships, weapons, secondary powers and equipment available.  Just because you picked an Engineering 'tanky' character doesn't stop you from flying glass cannon Defiants, and a high-damage Tactical can use the resilient, sluggish Galaxy.
3. Events.  This is the one saving grace for all the high-cost real-money ships; on a regular basis, you'll be able to grind for special limited event ships.  These are high-end and very effective; one of the recent ships is considered by some to be one of the tankiest ships in the game.
4. The story is actually pretty good.  MMO storylines tend to turn me off; they're clunky and ignorable.  While that certainly applies to a fair amount of STO, there are some excellently crafted set-pieces and missions.  Being kidnapped and brainwashed, seeing friends massacred after a peace conference goes wrong - and let's not forget the Romulan tutorial, where everyone you know is killed or kidnapped as you barely escape in a rusting hulk of a warbird.  Mass Effect it ain't, but I've been pleasantly surprised.
5. Speaking of which, you can tell that it's written by real Star Trek nerds.  Despite an incredible range of enemies, locations and concepts, just about everything can be tied into one of the episodes or movies.  Two of the endgame enemies are spun off from a couple of stand-alone episodes of Voyager, but they feel in-character and match up with what we saw of them in the series.  The Elachi, a recurring enemy for Romulan players, were designed from a single episode of Enterprise where we barely saw them, but the elaboration works perfectly.  Creepy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.  You'll also hear some very familiar voices - Worf, Sela, Harry Kim, Tuvok, Spock (RIP) and a fair number of minor characters from the series have lent their voice talents.
6. Levelling is fairly painless.  I remember attempting to get through WoW and giving up around Lvl 40 (Lich King era).  By comparison, STO has far fewer missions, and you can get a character to Lvl 50 in a week's casual play.  50-60 is a lot more tedious, but it's a lot less noticeable; you've unlocked all the important things, and it would be fair to say that the game really starts at 50.  Everything prior has been a warm-up tutorial.
7.  Endgame gear.  Many games require endless farming of a given boss in the hopes of a drop.  STO completely drops this idea; endgame gear is all obtained from Fleet (guild) equipment or the Reputation system.  Endgame content merely provides the means to afford this equipment.  It's entirely predictable, and I personally would prefer to know that I need ten runs to get what I want, rather than roll the dice of potentially getting it first time, but likely needing to run fifty times.  I get enough RNG nonsense from Warframe.

In conclusion... STO is by no means a perfect game.  That said, I would be comfortable in saying that it's one of the better offerings on the market.  Give it a week, and you'll be pleasantly surprised - or at least, you won't be bemoaning your lost time.

reviewText: I wanted a new MMO experience, and as a hardcore trek fan, I immediately leapt to this game thinking that it would satisfy the itch. While undoubtedly more loyal to its source material than any other star trek game I've ever played, this game really does count on its franchise name, rather than the actual merits of the game, to draw players in and create the experience. One of the very first enemies the starting missions will have you fight are the borg, which I and the NPC ship that was joining me for the quest defeated easily. The game constant throughs the most terrifying and iconic aliens of the Star Trek franchise at you (such as the borg, species 8472, the klingons, ect.), as if to remind you that this is in fact a star trek game, and you merciliously gun them all down. Part of what made those enemies so terrifying on the show was just how out-matched the federation ships were against them. When you see a borg cube one your screen, you should be weeping and just as scared as Picard was when he faced off against them, not happily blow one up after another with two other ships. The appearance of these enemies strikes me as fanservice--and bad fanservice at that, which there is plenty of throughout the game (did I mention that the captain you work under in the starting zone constaly refers to you as his Number 1?) If they had spent even half the time they spent thinking up stupid references trying to balance the combat and making the multiplayer exciting (which, by the way, you'll either be curb-stomping your way through or getting curb-stombed, there is no in between or concept of fair fights" or "evenly matched" opponents
date: but no one really does PvP anyway) they'd have a great game one their hands. In trying to make the game as "iconic" as possible
recommended: and not spending more time working on how to make the game as diverse

reviewText:
Vast and complex universe, lots of playstyles supported, most content optional, buggy.

There's a ton of content to play without paying a dime, but PVP and the highest-end PVE has a pay or grind to win" element.

Vast open universe (which lost significant content in the form of ground and space nebula missions that were evidently too hard to maintain) with various regions - be aware the regions do have difficulty levels. The "season" story missions scale with your level but do so unevenly
date: and rewards do not always scale. Fleet membership offers potential huge bonuses but requires a lot of resources.\n\nThe ships are amazing (some of them)
recommended: many of the story missions are too
hoursPlayed: a few are insanely irritating. You can skip many story missions. There is a "reputation" system that is pretty grindy but offers a lot of rewards.\n\nThere are bugs in this game that have gone unfixed for *years* and impact play

reviewText:
The only Star Trek MMORPG out there and it...is...AWESOME!!!


my only gripes and these are common to all MMORPG's are the community being a bit elitist at times and the occasional glitch *though the Devs usually have mind to patch glitches each week*

but if you love Star Trek or if you love MMORPG's give this one a try it is definitely worth it as you can fly all your favorite ships from the Miranda Class and the Constitution Class all the way up to the Galaxy Class and the Sovereign Class

plus you get to custom design  your character from a list of roughly 20 Species most MMORPG's don't give you 20 different species to choose from plus one species you can make your own *Alien*

the playable Factions include the Federation the Klingon Empire and the Romulan Republic

you can choose to be either a Tactical Officer a Science Officer or an Engineering Officer *each one has it's own abilities and traits*

the game itself takes place in 2409/2410 and the Federation and Klingons are at war again all the while the Romulan Republic are trying to form a new government while fighting the remnants of the Romulan Star Empire

i could go on and say what goes on in game but i don't wanna spoil the plot i want to let you find out for yourself what happens

reviewText:
Don't mind the almost 300 hour game time. I have WAY more hours logged on this game it's just that I had been using the non-steam game and launcher for a LONG time until I finally figured out it was also on steam. meh.

Okay ladies and gentlemen, I've gotta put first things first. This game is NOT, I repeat, NOT, pay to win. Now keep reading.

Anyway, let me get straight to the point. If you've never seen Start Trek before you'll be confused at first, because of the fact that you don't know $#!T about anything going on, and you won't understand almost anything in the game. However, the game does an excellent job of introducing all of the storylines and basically everything in the Star Trek universive to you, so basically, if you play this game long enough, you'll become a Trekkie, without even having watched any of the shows.

STO also has great missions, which are very immersive and interactive. Once you're done with one storyline, there'll always be many more to complete, as the STO team uploads new ones almost every 2-3 months. (Don't quote me.)

This game is absolutely free to play, which is of course, awesome. Every single weapon and ship can be aquired through a great system. Time and effort. Of course, it'll take much less time to aquire certain ships by purchasing them with Zen Points (Currency that is bought with real money), but it all depends on how you'd like to approach the game. I personally have not made a single ship purchase with Zen Points, and I still have a very strong ship that is capable of taking on any foe.

The game also has two im-game currency systems, Energy Credits and Dilithium. You'll be using these two currencies to buy most of your ships and equipment. Both of these currencies are easy to earn and the prices for items are never too high.

It has a great ranking-up and skill-tree system, and also has great PvP missions and PvE missions as well. And in PvP, your'e paired up with people of the same level, so you won't get obliterated by people who are much higher ranked than you.

There are many many things that I haven't mentioned in this review. The devs have put a great amount of time and effort into this amazing game and I think that they deserve praise for it.       But to sum it all up, you get to run around, shoot lasers at people, shoot bigger lasers at ships, get in game credits, buy really cool things, shoot at people more, and play Dabo. Yes, dabo. This game has gambling. What more do you want? Now download the dang game.

reviewText:
STO has had it's problems. On release it was buggy with poor controls and balancing. I'm pleased to say that the issues are mostly in the past, and the transition to free to play has been handled very well.

I've put a huge amount of time into this one, and have greatly enjoyed my experience both alone and with friends (although being an MMO, friends are recommended). There is an entertaining mix of ground and space combat, and branching dialogues with plenty of customisation options for your character, ship and play style.
Due to the numerous and ongoing updates there is now a pretty large amount of content to play through and keep you entertained.

To date I've never felt like I HAD to buy anything using real cash. From the starting levels through to the endgame, everything can be completed without paying a dime. There are a fairly large selection of ships, outfits and other customisation options which do require you to shell out some cash, however there is never the feeling of pay to win". Should you be willing to spend a little
date: Cryptic have catered well and there are some items which you may enjoy.\n\nAll in all
recommended: a solid free to play game. Worth a look - and for free

reviewText:
Star Trek Online has made a lot of improvments over the last five years.  What started out as a clunky mess full of good ideas and half formed systems has been refined, remade and polished into one of the most fun Free to Play MMOs out there.  Space and Ground combat has been redesigned to be fun and challenging rather than plodding and tedious and the rate of expansions and new Episodes (story missions) means that there is always somethign new to try.

That's not even taking into account the wealth of player created content in the Foundry missions (some of which are excellent) and the option to make missions yourself!  The game offers a lot of options and different activities with enough to meet the desires of almost every player type, Crafting, PVP, RP, PVE and even raiders.  Give it a download and have some Trek fun!

Live Long and Prosper

I would have preferd it to simply add to the aftermat of Dominion wars. not all this other stuff.


But all this is smaller stuff, it's still the best star trek game made. its stll my favorite and only MMO I can play.

reviewText:
Can I just say, if you really love Star Trek, and you really love  MMORPGs, you will love this game. I am a huge fan of anything science fiction. When i discovered this game and found out that you can captain your own ship, I nearly exploded from excitment. The game did not disapoint. In the following paragraphs I will state things I enjoy about this game, and the very few cons that I have.
Pros- This game lets you captain a starship and fight any enemy the federation has ever faced. You fight Klingons, Romulans, Borg, Gorn, Cardassians, and even more! The stories do an extremely good job of putting you in the shoes of a captain and the space combat is fantastic. This game is extremely customizable and hundreds of different abilities for space comabt, and ground combat are available making each players build unique! Some people complain that once you reach level 60, the game is a cash grab. For people that aren't patient, yes it is. They complain that in order to receive tier 6 ships, you need to spend money. This is not entirely true becasue every year there are two or three events that give you the opportunity to win t6 starships. Sure, its a long process to win them but in the long run it's worth it! Or, if you've been a veteran for a decent amount of time, you may receive a free t6 ship from arc games thanking you for playing their game. Thats how I got mine! Also, going back to the campaign, the Iconian War story is fanominal! Also you can captain Klingon and Romulan ships. Nuff said.
Cons- I don't have many issues with this game except for a couple small issues. I think the ground combat could be a little better improved. Unless you're extremely duked out in shields and weapons at level 60, you will die alot. That being said, I do agree with some of the issues that many people have about the game being a cash grab. Yes, you can get free t6 ships, but if you want a t6 ship without waiting, it will cost 30$ of real money. Thats way too much to spend for just a decent ship in an MMO. For people that may not be as patient, this game is such a cash grab.
Overall, I have enjoyed this game alot. There is so much to do in it and its space combat is extremely engaging and addictive. If you aren't the most patient person out there, this game could potentially become a cash grab but if you have the patience at level 60, you will receive a t6 ship in time. All in all, get this game. Its so much fun!

reviewText:
So, I decided to finally write up a review for this game. I figure that around 370 hours of play is enough to be able to know what I'm writing about.

So, the first question you have to ask of Star Trek Online: Does it feel like Star Trek? The short answer is kind of. The long answer is yes and no. Whilst it has familiar staples of the franchise, it is also lacking in some elements. For example, more exploration that DIDN'T invariably lead into combat encounters wouldn't go amiss. I won't say it doesn't feel like Star Trek, but it feels almost exclusively like seasons six and seven of DS9 and season three of Enterprise. It has some Trek aspects, but it feels more like a Trek skin for a generic Space MMO and action based MMO. It does, however, have some nice fan service in appearances by existing characters, with several, including Spock, Worf, Sela, Tom Paris, Harry Kim, Seven of Nine, Neelix, the Doctor and Miral Paris, being voiced by their actors from the shows. An opening narration by Leonard Nimoy and an EMH voiced by Zachary Quinto are also both nice touches.

What's worth considering on the lack of Trek feel to this game, is that it is somewhat remedied by the foundry; the user generated content is, in my experience, of great quality more often than not. In fact, there have been occassions where I've felt the foundry content had come out better than the content released by Cryptic / Perfect World / Whatever they want to call themselves now. A prime example is the Breen missions; whilst a fun little arc, some of the missions involved in it can be awkward to play. That's not to say all user created content is amazing and infinitely better than the stuff the studio puts out, just that it often has a more Star Trek feel to it.

My next point is in regards to the playable classes. At the start of the game, you pick one of three factions, between Federation, Klingons and Romulans. It's worth noting that, while playing as a Romulan, you play as a member of the new Romulan Republic faction, NOT a member of the Romulan Star Empire, so if you're hoping to be the bad guy, your bubble's burst, I'm sorry. Each of these factions have their own stories, with the Federation being my favourite, the Romulans proving suitably intriguing but the Klingon story feels somewhat closer to how they have been portrayed in Trek before, so I find myself with a bias towards them over the Romulans.

Once you've chosen your faction, we then get into the actual classes, broken up into the three basic areas of Starfleet; Tactical (i.e. Worf, Tuvok, Reed), Operations (i.e. Scotty, Data, O'Brien) or Science (i.e. Spock, Jadzia Dax, T'pol), with each filling their own role not quite typical of MMO's; Tactical tends to work best with the smaller, faster ships with run and gun tactics, Operations works with the big cruisers and dreadnoughts, and Science works with a sort of intermediary with more buffs. That's not to say you can't play a Tactical character in a Dreadnought (I do!) or a Science character in a light escort, it's just their abilities are more geared towards the ship types mentioned before.

My one gripe with this game is the micro transactions; they aren't micro at all! Zen works out as almost 1p per 1 Zen, so when you see a ship for 3000 Zen, you're looking at about £30.00! Of course, Zen can be farmed via Dilithium mining. However, at the moment, it is 260 odd Dilithium per Zen, with an 8000 per character per day cap on amount you can refine; that translates to a lot of grinding for Dilithium. It doesn't help that the Z-store ships are noticably better than those found in the ship store that you get a free ship from as you go through. Wit hthe introduction of the new T6 ships, this is more noticable than ever, and I hope to see some real F2P T6 ships implemented soon!

Overall, it's a good enough game. It's not a great Star Trek game, but it does pay fan service in the right places at least. My final opinion is; I'd reccomend this, but Trekkies, be patient with it, it'll take roughly as much patience as the Trek reboots do, so if you enjoy them, you'll enjoy this, if you don't, maybe give this one a miss.

I would recomend it. It feels like I am playing in the Star Trek universe. I LOVE playing with the starships.

It feels like a mess of systems with a weak focus, but that may be because I like single player games as opposed to MMOs. (I feel similar about The Old Republic) Although this one is less focused due to the dual systems of space and ground combat. That said, both space and ground are not bad, but really don't feel like a part of a triple A title.

It's free! so give it a shot.

If you love star trek, you will probably enjoy it. Otherwise it may be best to give it a pass.

reviewText:
STO was a great game at one point.  It's a fairly mediocre game as of late.

Many bad/questionable choices have caused major imbalances in the game, frustrated long time players, and shown that PWE/Cryptic is trying to heavily monitize the game at the expense of the players.

However, that being said, there is much good to be said about STO as well.

1) Decent storylines that pick up where the TV episodes and movies left off.  Cryptic has done a great job of revisiting many of the lesser known races in the STO universe, and bringing many unfinished story lines to a close.

2) Ships, ships, and more ships.  All the amazing ships we know and love as well as quite a few retrofits/refits that bring our favoties up to par with the 25th century.  I love taking out my 23rd century Excelcisior class cruiser and wiping the floor with the Borg or even other players.  Nothing is more embarassing then a 200 year old ship tearing your brand new top of the line cruiser to shreds.

3) Decent player base.  Social interaction is recommended, but not required.  You can go a long ways without ever having to say hello to another player.  However, joining a fleet should be one of the first things that you do, so that you can get further, get better gear, etc.

4) Decent selection of real world money ships, costumes, etc.  Some of them are obvious money grabs, but some of them are just plain awesome too.

5) Seasonal events like the Summer event at Risa and Q's Winter Wonderland help break the slowness in 'seasons' (aka expansions).

6) Ground combat is 'okay'.  Its not up to par with the space combat, but it is certainly playable and how you best explore the main story lines.

All in all, if you like Star Trek, then you'd probably like STO.  If you've never played an MMO before, or don't have much experience in the Star Trek universe, you can try this game, but be prepared for a learning curve.

reviewText:
I had played this for seval hundred hours a few years ago, got bored, and left.  I decided to come back to see if things had gotten more interesting.  What I found is, if you're a new player, it is nearly impossible to do much of anything in this game anymore.

You will spend hours waiting for a pve que to fill up to get currency for a grindy reputation system that everyone who plays already has finished.  The EC exchange currency has been devalued to a point where anything useful is unobtainable without saving for months, or possibly years, due to the lack of ability to collect valuable loot because no one does pve ques.  The crafting system will take years to complete without any money invested, or you could throw money at the game and it will still take a year and a couple thousand dollars, just to allowed to have the random chance at something that may or may not be useful.

Many more examples exist, but to sum up the problems:  Lack of players makes a grindy game an impossible grind.  If you've never played before, don't waste your time.  If you haven't played in a while, it's more waiting for the same thing you've done already.

reviewText:
My first review on here.

I played this game since an old friend introduced me to it when it went free to play years ago. Even bought a lifetime supscription for the hell of it. It was on and off. It reintroduced me to Star Trek, and it can be fun to play even with some of the big problems it has

I'm going to revise this review and make it shorter and less bias. It does have some of the original cast members from the shows providing their voices of the original characters like Worf, Nog, Tuvok, etc. And Morn is played by well...Morn. It has an active but small role playing community where one could feel like a real character in the Trek universe. The guild or fleet system is pretty robust with many benefits to fleet members like access to ships and gear that only fleet members can get. The game's crew does regularly add new content almost monthly. And there is plenty to do here like random events, play adventure zones, fight in battlezones(yet few of these are pvp zones), practice your character's crafting or R&D, and play STFs and other more team-based instances with firends or complete strangers.

To top it all off, it is ALL FREE! Almost anything can be bought without using any real money whatsoever. You will have to prioritize what you want if you want to play to earn, but one can just get whatever they want in the game just by grinding it. I wish I discovered this before I bought the lifetime supscription. Biggest DOH moment in my life. LOL!XD. But I still payed some money here and there to support it anyway.

Now for the negatives. This game does get vary buggy. So buggy even old bugs will come back from time to time. Many of these bugs are funny, but some are game breaking like a broken mail system. And there are bugs and borderline exploiting bugs that have never been fixed for years. The community can get a bit too negative or toxic in places. And the gameplay can get unbalanced as its  seems to be about damage and not much else.

Even though I give this game a thumbs down for all those cons, this game can still be vary fun. And this game is vary generous for an MMO as its vary possible to get whatever one wants without paying for it at all if one knows how to budget and set in-game financial priorities. For that sense, I recommend this game 100%. But a fair warning, it will have some serious rough edges that can hurt your experience.

reviewText:
Star Trek Online (STO) is a free to play mmorpg.

I have been playing on and off since the start of Star Trek Online,  Just added STO on Steam just long enough to write the review.  I have 1 account that i paid money on and 3 accounts that are Free to Play.  I use the STO ARC game client only.

Positves:

STO is great if you want to play for FREE as a simple starship captain in the Star Trek MMO universe.  You don't have to pay any real money to experience the complete Star Trek universe.

You can make 3 different faction captains ( Federation, Romulan, Klingon ) on 1 account.

The level cap is now level 60.  Plenty of extra specializations and traits you can add to your captain to improve ground and space combat.

It is easy to get to level 50 in a short amount of time, but going to level 60 will take much grinding and time.

Basic gear is plentyfull in loot drops and mission rewards.

Plenty of free cosmetic customization is available for your captains, bridge crew and ships.

You can play minigames to earn dilithium ore that can be sold for a little store currency or buy a ship.

Plenty of PVE missions that are soloable and a few Co-Op battle areas.  Plenty of missions and areas for you to explore with you and your 4 bridge crew. There is player created missions in the Foundry to try out.  Plenty of Events to play through out the year.  STO has Crafting.

Free players get a ship each rank up to tier 4. You can buy some extra ships from the exchange, if you can earn enough energy credits or if you find free giveaway codes or earn enough dilithium.  3 types of ships: Escort = DPS, Science = Support, Cruiser = Tank.

Has a mini-game that you can send your duty officers and your fleet of ships on their own missions and you reap the rewards of their success.

STO is also Free to Play friendly, not as bad with limitations added to free accounts as other games. Usually e-mail / chat unlocks with 20 plus hours in-game.  Inventory and bank is big enough, has in-space access to bank and email.  Free players have enough slots in exchange to sell items. But Free to play account are limited in number of bridge officer slots.

-------------------------------------

Negatives:

The game is still very buggy, but it has been Expanded, nerfed, simplified, reworked and changed over the years.  The game is pretty laggy at times, it has not always been.  Lately, The devs keep breaking old things and not fixing anything.  Game client crashes happen often now.  When the game works for you, it is great.

Seems like the Steam game client is buggier than the STO website game client.  If you have Mac, learn to use a Virtual Machine player or dual booting with Windows 7 loaded and use the Windows Arc game client.

If you are into playing PVP, forget about PVP, it is dead because of power creep.

Very few reasons for players to team up in STO, except for the Co-Op instances..

Very Pay to Win and very Grindy game close to end level.  PWI is milking this game for money, but if you can buy PWI money cards they can be used to buy STO stuff.  You have to spend real money to play in style or be competative at elite end level content.

Give it a try. Play it for FREE only.

reviewText:
MMOs are tricky things, and what they do more than anything else is excel in one area and totally crash and burn in another.

Star Trek Online is, in this regard, a quintessential MMO.

When you are piloting your ship, its an engaging, albeit repetitive experience that is well executed, beautifully rendered and full of promise.

When you walk around on your own two feet, you have to wonder why the developers even bothered.

Recent reworking of many portions of this game have improved the overall experience, but the planet-bound experience is pretty miserable.

The graphics for the 3rd person experience are shockingly bad, the movement is relatively humorous, but not necessarily in a good way, the animation is weak and the combat while better than you might imagine, the AI of your crew mates" is disappointing.

In contrast

reviewText:
The game is truly immersive,one of the few games in which i've read all the dialogue and actually cared about what's going on around me.

In Star Trek Online, the scale of the universe is immense, filled with hundreds of enemy factions to take on including: Romulan (Friendly Now), Cardassian, Dominion, Klingon, Hirogen, Voth etc. The game offers a variety of ships to command not to mention the ships of some of the most formidable enemies of the Star Trek Galaxy.

The overall story throughout the game is incredibly satisfying, and rather addictive if you enjoy Star Trek, then you will enjoy being your own captain and making your own legacy amongst the stars.

Game looks alright,not the best but it can be easily overlooked.Voice acting is not that great either,the options you're given during dialogues are not as important,which i dont particularly like as im used to BioWare's story telling,but that's just my opinion.

Ship piloting is pretty fun,plenty of customisation options for both the ship and your crew.

I got into this game with no prior knowledge about the enormous lore of Star Trek,but i loved it anyway and it really is fun to learn about all the factions,races and relations between them.

If you're tired of WoW look alike mmorpgs and you want to experience a universe that you can thoroughly explore as a captain of your very own ship this is just a game for you.

reviewText:
Most of my time logged in this game is pre-DR. Since DR was released it's like cryptic has taken the time to make the Mac version (sue me) unplayable.

Here is how I launch the game on my 2012 MBP with 16gigs of ram and an i7 processor.

1) Launch game from steam
2) Watch launcher crash
3) Verify program files. Failure to do so will result in the launcher crashing on startup, no exceptions.
4) Launch game again. Launcher will now create two separate instances of itself, with one of them going unresponsive immediately.
5) Launch the game via the launcher.
6) Sit and watch the game load for 5+ minutes. If you alt+tab out to a different program, the game will crash.
7) Once the game has loaded, play for five-fifteen minutes before the game crashes while asking for your administrator password (??????)

Before delta rising, I'd recommend this to anyone. Now, I can only say stay away""

reviewText: This game is obviously written and designed by people who love the Star Trek franchise, as almost each mission is filled with trivia from the television shows and movies. The ship combat is very solid, but the ground combat is very basic and not very engaging. Some of the missions are better designed than others - I hope you get through the Cardassian storyline, but you will have to endure the chore that is the Romulan storyline to get there. There are a huge amount of customizations for you to choose from for your ships and characters, however most options are locked behind the paywall. Once you've reached the end of the storylines, there isn't much to do other than reputation grind and PVP, but the game permits player-created content, which definitely extends the life of this game.

reviewText: This is a game I played with the intent to dislike it. I mean, a franchise I did not care for, a MMO, sci fi setting..\nGuess what- it didn't happen as the world was well presented, immersive, and I was given total freedom to set up my character, own my own ship, and even configure that one to my likings generously. You can play it entirely free, the added bonuses of subscribing and/or buying cash store items tend to be rather marginal, I ended up paying mainly to support the developers, but at its core it is still a nice looking RPG-style thing with variety between character-ground combat, or exciting ship to ship fights, and no need to do boring grind quests as you can level up with an interesting storyline mission. There is still ongoing support for this, too. watch out though, you might learn a bit more about the series than you wanted..

reviewText:
Star Trek Online is the first MMO I've ever given a really fair shake to. Generally, the MMO formula doesn't appeal to me, but after reading several positive reviews, I gave this one a try.

The game itself is very attractive, especially with the graphical settings turned all the way up. This is definitely a Star Trek universe, with lots of visual cues  from the TV shows.

This game delivers lots of solo content, which is what piqued my interest. And it's true, this MMO is mostly a solo venture. You'll see other ships flying around, and other people at stardock, but you rarely interact with them. It's like 1,000 people playing solitare together.

Star Trek Online has a compelling space-combat system. You can really trick up your ship, too, if you care to. But this doesn't save the game from it's very repetitive missions, and very complicated economy.

End result: I lost interest. Total time invested, about 10 hours.

Do you remember the launch of this game? What a snowball bad start right? Klingon not finish no story line in klingons also pvp based. And the lag disconnection issues account that was so bad i even cry a little because i love star trek. However 2014 The game is change a lot. New contend new ships new missions new events is it good yah it is, is it the best hell no. But its for sure 200% better than at start. The Free to Play model is fine its not pay to win because you`re doing more pve than pvp at the end pvp is not worth looking for in this game so ignore that one. However there is a downside to everything like every mmorpg the end game is really the endgame you can farm special items or crew or whatever you want to do. You can change everything not only your ship or you but even your crew your deck of the ship and even costum your engine increasing it at your taste. There are cookie builds on the net to squeeze the maximum of your char and ship. But thats your taste of gaming.

Give it a chance play its free you know no money is needing to it. Perhaps if you like it badly you can buy a great ship you like. Fear deal right?

I love this game it's awsome i suggest it to everyone

Edit 1.
I have been playing this game since 2012 I absolutly enjoy this game
But lets get into basics about it's features and how much it's enjoyable ,
It has been around for almost 5 years now as of this review edit It has PVE and PVP content both enjoyable with the right people it has 3 factions Fed, KDF, RP ( RP - Romulan Republic not Roleplay ) , Most of the Missions are Enjoyable about 98% mostly the Romulan republic ones since they're the newest storyline the game has a strong Community don't let anyone fool you , The game's mechanic's are ok i give them a 4/5 , the game's Graghics are old based on the cryptic engine from of course cryptic they have not upgraded to a new engine yet hopefully will do so , So I give it a 3/5 with that the storylines i give them a 5/5,  the support system Hasn't improved since it was like on the last website and has actually degraded since it transfered to arc games so i give that a 2/5 as for the playerbase there is a strong community of trolls such trolls are part of some Fleets ( Guilds ) and are highly disruptive and can impair your gameplay significantly  I highly suggest you avoid them there is a fragile community of roleplayers fragile because What i recently just said ( the Troll groups atleast the main branch are Starfleet Dental, Nerds of prey, and Shutup wesley )  ( I'AM NOT POINTING OUT ANYONE OR DISSING THESE 3 FLEETS I'AM ONLY SPARING PEOPLE FROM A VERY UNHAPPY TIME BY WARNING THEM ) but unlike some troll groups these are highly avoidable and can be ignored easily if you wish, As for other unmentioned features and mechanics etc I give them a 5/5 , This game is only enjoyable as you make it if you make it hard and difficult then the gameplay will NOT be enjoyable there is an expansion now that raised the Level cap from Level 50 to Level 60 Levels 1 - 50 are essentially easy to get through if you stick to getting 10+ Level's a day you can be level 50 in 5 days or less as for Level 60+ thats more difficult it can take as long as a MONTH to get there from 50 - 60 , I highly suggest when leveling to do patrols first before the main mission's

Edit 1, ( Update )
This just an update for the review under edit 1, I recently tried to play the game and found it very buggy and laggy as well as when moving rubber banding all over the place and lots of people have been reporting this issue to no help at all from the devs or Gm's the people who run the game ( PWE ) do not care for the game anymore all they do is post content rather then fix the content they already have making more bugs and issues as they go and making the game more unenjoyable all they want is to lure people in to spend money on ships and other items rather then fix the content and bugs the game is also super unbalanced thanks to the last expansion ( Delta Rising ) which they have yet to fix and have not given any tips as to if they are doing so I still enjoy this game so i will continue to play it but until they fix this issue i will not be spending a dime on the game I still recommend it because the more people that play the game and the more that experience the issue and report it could push the devs and gm's to actually fix the problems.

reviewText:
Star Trek Online is a game made by Cryptic Studios and Published by Perfect World Entertainment. The game had a very poor start, and was labelled as a 'dead MMO' a very long time ago. Since those dark days however, Star Trek Online has taken a miraculous turn for the better. It's as if someone got up from their depression in the developpers studio and said 'Let's kick some serious ***, people!'
Well, whatever the case may be? It worked. Star Trek Online is an absolutely 'amazing' game, with everything from brand new graphics, to hourly events, to monthly special events that do not simply throw new content at you, but actually introduces it through an event!
The game also has a huge amount of Roleplay potential, with the ability to enter the bridge of your own ship, and even, if you have Starfleet/Klingon standard ships, go into the rest of the ship, such as crew quarters, etc.

Star Trek Online, at first release, took place in 2409, 30 years after the events of the movie Star Trek: Nemesis. It largely follows the storyline of Star Fleet, but can also include the Klingon Empire(After rank 25 has been achieved). Since Legacy of Romulus has been released, you can also now play as a Romulan.

Gameplay:
Star Trek Online has two gameplay modes. It has ship control, and it has regular person control. Much of the combat used to, in the old terrible days, happen in space, and ground combat was an eye sore. Now, Ground combat is just as viable(albeit a bit harder) than space combat, and features everything from Melee to healing to ranged to ballistic artillery. There are more types of weapons than you care to think about; Rifles, snipers, miniguns, dual wielding pistols, swords, bat'leths, Vulcan lirpas, shotguns, grenades. And for each of those? There's a different style of damage; Phaser, Disruptor, Plasma, Antiproton, each of which look different. The choices in terms of weaponry are literally endless, you couldn't make enough characters to try them all! The same goes for ships, giving you everything from torpedoes to cannons to phasers to custom special weapons unlocked through events.
The gameplay of this game has gone from an F, to an A++.

Character Creator:
Yes, this thing needs its own subsection, deal with it XD
The game features 3 different classes, each of which have some specific strengths and weaknesses, but dont in any way limit you to a certain type of ship etc. Any class, can fly any ship, use any weapon, etc.

Tactical Officer(Red shirt): A strange mixture between DPS and Support, the Tactical officer lends a hand to his allies with buffs to damage and evasion, while also dishing out some impressive damage. They primarily fight ground combat with either melee, ranged, or grenades, and in space, they prefer small, agile escort fighters.

Science Officer(Blue Shirt): The primary source of physical healing and support in the game. They suffer in damage, but do healing and support where others cannot, such as Heal over Time and defense bonuses. They prefer to fly Science Vessels, or Carriers.

Engineering Officer(Yellow Shirt): The primary source of damage and shield healing in the game. They do a little bit of everything, and are profoundly Overpowered in the game at the moment. An engineer can lay down turrets or Mortar gunners, and can absolutely obliterate enemies with orbital strikes, grenades, mortars, sentry turrets, and an impressive affinity for melee weapons. They are also the primary tank of the game, taking impressive agro with their damage and having the strongest Shield healing capabilities in the game, keeping them alive while doing RIDICULOUS amounts of damage. Did I say their damage is crazy? They prefer to fly the large, hulking cruiser ships, nicknamed 'Space whales' due to their slow turn rate, but what they lack in maneuverability, they make up for in brute strength, and survivability.

As for races. There are more races in this game than I care to list. There is pretty much every single species ever to be featured in Star Trek, EVER. And if none of those appeal to you? Heck, MAKE YOUR OWN! Yeah! The character creator lets you custom design your own alien species! Wanna hail from the Gamma Quadrant? Never been seen before by Alpha Quadrant inhabitants? Not a problem! Just design it and write the lore for it!


What kinda ships are there, then? (Let me again repeat that EVERY CLASS above can actually fly ANY ship thrown at them, except they have their 'best choices' all the same.)

Escorts: The most iconic one being the USS Defiant(Deep Space Nine). Small, and very powerful damage dealers. They are the only type of ships that can fit Dual Heavy Cannons, some of the most serious weapons you've ever seen. They're tiny ships that can set a galaxy ablaze, blasting everything in front of them into nothingness. Though they're fragile, and will be easily overpowered if focused by enemy ships.

Science Vessels: The most Iconic being USS Voyager(Voyager). They're not too strong with their weapons, but they have a little ace in their sleeves called 'exotic damage'. Their primary weapon is their deflector dish, and they can conjure up all manner of strange phenomenons in the universe, from rifts to gravitational anomalies that rip ships to pieces. They might be the healers, and supporters in a firefight, but don't corner one and force it to fight back. You'll regret it.

Carriers: The largest of all the ships. These ships are a sort of sub-ship for Science Commanders to choose if their aim is to tank. The ship itself is no longer the primary source of damage, instead its allowed to focus entirely on defenses and shield power. Instead, they leave the damage to their arsenal of fighters. They dispath squadrons of tiny, very hard to hit fighter ships that can, in unison, utterly overwhelm a larger ship. Flying a carrier well takes skill, but once you have the control of the fighters down, you're a force to be reckoned with in a space war.

Cruisers: The most iconic one being USS Enterprise series. these are the massive, floating citadels of the galaxy. They sport crew sizes as big as small cities, and have the largest potential for tanking of any ship. Despite their affinity for survivability, they still have an impressive array of offensive weaponry, and can, if flown right, be a serious problem all by itself for the enemy. Nicknamed Space Whales.

Special Ships: These can only be unlocked by opening lockboxes, which cost real money, OR bought for very high prices in the in-game auction house. Some can also be unlocked by buying them with a special, hard to gain currency called Lobi Crystals.

Graphics: The graphics are a little bit hit or miss. In terms of their fuction, they are adequate, however they are by no means as good as other, new-age titles. Still, the graphics are impressive considering the hardships this game went through, and are still great eyecandy when floating around in space :3

Overall Score:

I'm gonna give this game 9.2/10. It is just doing too many things right to not deserve it. I would have preferred giving it 10/10, but the ONE draw back this game has, the MAJOR archilles heel of this title? It's free to play nature. The game gives you everything for free, that's true, 'except' for special ships, new outfits, and even some specific races, like Federation Klingons, or Caitian/Ferasan(Cat people for the furries <3 ) The game is, largely, a 'lockbox' hell game, and if you are not interested in that, and can ignore it? The game is at least a 9.8/10, ALMOST PERFECT, but not quite.

Do I recommend this game? Honey, there's no MMO out there which I can safely recommend more earnestly, than this one. If you like Star Trek, and MMOs? This is a game you absolutely have to play.

If you live in China, Taiwan, Russia, Hong Kong, South Korea, Macau, Vietnam or Egypt? You will not be able to play this game!
