reviewText:
I've been playing this game on and off for around three years, have a lifetime sub, and five alts to my main. My hours on Steam are not accurate as I have played this through the STO launcher, Champions Online launcher, and Arc. As someone who has well over 1000 hours invested into this game, I feel obligated to tell you this game is in no way P2W or paywalled. The people who say these things are either bad at the game or can't be bothered to get dilithium and buy ships. NO ship is overpowered, bar the Scimitar which is just ridiculous. Some ships excel at their role, yes, but there is no overpowered. PVP is dead, so anyone using that as a measurement is fighting against people who have invested time into their characters.

On to the actual review. STO is a Star Trek MMORPG developed by Cryptic Studios, a company that is really passionate about their babies. There are glorious space battles to be had, as you go from ensign to admiral over your character's career. You start off against the Klingons in tradition Trek fashion and things quickly escalate. Missions are divided into arcs that act almost as seasons, with some very impressive set pieces that are played around with.

The character customization is almost overwhelming, with just about every species having a place and the ability to customize your own alien species. This customizability extends to uniforms and bridge officers, who are like your companions in other games. You choose their looks, their weapons, and their abilities.

Every character, yourself included, is divided into three careers: Engineering, Science, and Tactical. These give you basic abilities that you can use regardless of your ship, all of which are fairly useful. Tacs excel at damage, sci  toons can pull some space debuffing magic, and engineers are gods of fortifying their hulls with extreme amounts of health. Any captain can pilot any ship, regardless of what type of ship that is. There is no forced progression path into a certain ship.

I'll touch on ships here, since that's what we're looking for. There are dozens of ships ranging from Tier 1 to Tier 6. You get a new ship every ten levels, stopping at 40. 40-50 is T5, with everything above 50 being T6. T6 ships can be bought for real money, earned frome events, or bought by converting dilithium to zen.

The conversion rate is around 160 dil per zen, which fluctuates a fair bit. T6 ships cost 3000 zen, which might seem like a lot because it is. You can refine 8000 dilithium per day as a basic player, so it'll take a while to earn and refine that much. Once you fall into a nice pattern, this isn't something that seems grindy.

The difficulty of the game is fairly low, although the average player might have some difficulties if they aren't aware of how the game works. This is a simple, but shockingly deep game. Don't worry about loot until you hit 50, then find what you want to do. The game doesn't have to be just about damage, everyone has a place. Check out r/STO and r/STOBuilds if you have problems, and join RedditChat ingame.

You may see me flying around as Johnny B. Obvious@prrah-khet, so feel free to add me as a friend and ask as many questions as you need. As long as you are willing to learn, I can help you. See you out there, cadets!

reviewText:
If you're a Star Trek fan, then you'll want to play this. Obviously, PW makes their money by having microtransactions. However, despite this, it's still equitable for the F2P player. As the game description says, it's like being inside the show. Sector narration is done by Leonard Nimoy, Michael Dorn reprises his role as Worf and there are other familiar characters. If you're a Star Trek fanboy like me, then you'll see this game as a time suck. It's not the most visually stunning game out there but it's a lot of fun.

Edit 1: Recently, Tim Russ reprised his role as Tuvok during a Dyson Sphere event.

Edit 2: Now that I have more time on record, I can add a few things. My view about the game above is still the same. However, I will take the time to add a few things. As I said before, it helps if you're a Star Trek fan to begin with. You get to play with the ship types you saw in the different series and you get to visit the places you could only see on TV. I will caution you that the story takes place some 30 years after the events of the last Star Trek movie (no, not the new ones...I mean Nemesis). If you take that into consideration, you'll realize that it's a whole new take on the franchise.

Edit 3: I mentioned before that there are microtransactions. Really, the best ships are there and it wouldn't hurt to drop some money on Zen to get a few of them. That being said, you seriously don't have to. What you're really paying for are the consoles that come with them that give you some neat abilities. When you hit max level, you can get all kinds of equipment by running PvE/PvP queues that evens the playing field. So, you don't need to buy anything at all.

Edit 4: With the Legacy of Romulus update they did, the current mechanics seem to favor the Romulans since you can choose a side. Their ships seems to have the advantage in fights and function in multiple capacities. That being said, the disparity isn't actually there. Each race has their strong suit and each race is deficient somwhere.

reviewText:
I honestly don't know what steam says my play time is. I have been using the old STO launcher from before ARC or Steam.  I played the game for about two years.  I truly loved it until the latest cash grab that came with the level cap increase to 60.  There are places where you can see the amount of money necessary to get the former end-game gear to the new end-game gear without spending a full year grinding to get it there.

I loved the game, played competitively in PvP with a lot of great people.  I was not a free player.  Probably spent around $3-400 on this game before the cap inrease.  Now it seems I would have to spend around $80-$120 more to get any one of my many ships to their new potential...Or spend nearly a year on the grind.

I'll miss it, but I won't be touching this thing ever again.  This one goes out to Lag Industries and the Sad Pandas!  I'll miss you guys!

reviewText:
It's free so give it a try, but don't give them your money.

I had an issue recently where an in-game item that I had paid money towards was accidentally deleted because of a bug. The support department refused to return it, didn't have the decency to tell me why they wouldn't/couldn't and even threatened to ban my account if I pressed the matter.

The developers of the game openly have contempt for their players calling them morons, exploiters, whiners, you name it. There seems to be a real toxic attitude behind the scenes at certain levels of this company.


For a review of the game...


I'm a life-long Star Trek fan. I came here looking for a fix after not being impressed by the new movies and I found it for a while. There is plenty to explore and the ships are done well and can be fun to fly.

Then you start to realise that every mission is essentially the same. Warp in, kill a few waves of bad guys and warp out. Starfleet don't do diplomacy or exploration anymore, they just kill everything. No questions asked.

The endgame is the same. Repeating the same few missions over and over to gain slightly better equipment to do the same few missions over and over but slightly quicker. Everything is a pointless grind. The only real reason to stay is the friends you make along the way.

To summarise, it's a moderately ok space shooter that plays upon your nostalgia and love of a tv show with skins, music and a bit of voice acting. Everything is a grind and hidden behind timegates and endless grind/paywalls. To make any real progress you either need a fat wallet or to play the game like a full-time job.

There are far better gaming experiences out there.

reviewText:
Star Trek Online used to be better before Delta Rising. The main offenses after the new expansion lie in the realms of balance. Release after release, there seems to be very little deliberation about releasing new items and mechanics. They are, for the most part, terribly broken. PvP is utterly a joke, and even PvE now suffers the consequences, as the empty queues can tell.

Many other systems are equally aggravating. Crafting and upgrading, both tied behind time gates and random number generators. When you craft or upgrade an item, you cannot choose the mods - they're random. Which may turn your crafted item into vendor trash, and your resources spent for nothing. Not to mention the terrible long time gates -- 20 hours to craft a single endgame item. I haven't seen any of this in the other good MMOs I used to play.

To not be completely negative about this, certain areas of the game get proper attention and listen to player feedback. They're mostly related to art: costumes, ship models, and environment. The new Club 47, released a couple weeks prior to the date of this post, is truly awesome. But you can only go so far dancing all night long in this game, if anywhere.

As a fan of the game genre (flying a starship, having a crew), it is sad to see this game being destroyed by poor development decisions. If you are a fan of Star Trek (I am not really), you may find the stories interesting.

reviewText: Star Trek online is a game which follows in the footsteps of the franchise T.v shows in that the story and characters are always respectful of the lore but like the new movies alot of the plot revolves around time-travel and dimensional travel but so what, it seems the new season is focused on previously untold and unexplored concepts around Millenia-dormant threats from numerous ancient races which push the boundaries of the  lore. I think many of the story mission sagas would actually make good comics or novels but most players lament not having conversation choices impact the story in a significant way, even though there are many opportunities to play as evil or good. The lengthy Rep system and new Research schools and specialization trees cretainly breathed life into the game for dedicated players, as well as new ships available to all players who complete events during winter and summer. No player need be left behind" in terms of ships and equipment

reviewText: I'm a long time player and have only seen this game improve. There have been a few hiccups here and there but ultimately the game only gets better. They have a great free-to-play model. If you have the time, anything in the game can be had without spending a dime. The best  end-game gear is earned in game, not by purchasing it in the cash shop. So, no...this game isn't 'pay-to-win'.\nCash shop ships, costumes, personnel, etc... can be purchased as a free-to-play player without spending a cent. You just have to earn in game currency known as Dilithium, and then trade it in the dilithium exchange market for Zen (which is the cash bought currency used in the cash shop). There are a few exceptions to this. There are a few rewards for subscribers and lifetime account holders that can only be had by purchasing or subscribing, but none of these rewards are game breaking, nor do they effect game play.

reviewText:
*Review edited slightly due to a patch that added confirmation for skilltree choices, I'm not sure when exactly it was patched in.

I've been on the fence about which way to lean for a long time, I want to recommend it because I've always been a big fan of Star Trek and this is the only ST MMO, but I just can't.

To start with, it has consistently gone downhill since cryptic (the developer) was sold off by Atari and bought by perfect world international. Anyone familiar with PWI knows they're at about the level of nexon for terrible support, outrageous prices, and poor to nonexistent communication. Well, I'll give cryptic this, they do blog posts and announcements about everything, have frequent livestreams, and devs will occasionally chime in on forum topics, but when it comes to support? Good luck. You may or may not get a canned response when you submit a ticket, and may or may not ever get a real person to reply to you after you reply to the canned response, and they know their support is beyond terrible because they completely removed the satisfaction survey people could fill out after their support ticket was closed.

The prices for most of the premium content is also ridiculous (especially ships.....$25-$30 per for endgame ships), and even things that are basic in most MMOs cost money here. Want to rename your character? Pay up. But the rename tokens don't even work properly and it shows your old name in a lot of in game dialogue. Did you pick a wrong skill somewhere in the newly revamped skill tree that just made things more confusing? Guess it sucks to be you, pay up for that reskill token. You can buy 30+ character slots, but the game has been made so alt unfriendly with all the reputations and specializations to grind for that it's mostly pointless to play more than one character anymore unless you're really hardcore and can juggle 2 or 3. And the expansion themed bundles? $130 for a few ships, a handful of costumes, maybe a title or two, and some master keys? I don't know about anyone else but I can't justify dropping $130 unless there's some physical goods to go with it.

New content" is frequently added to the game but it's almost always just a tie-in to some new cash item
date: most often gacha style lockboxes which aren't cash items themselves but require master keys to open
recommended: which are cash items. Lately any new features are just tweaks to or revamps of existing mechanics
hoursPlayed: which always cause a slew of bugs that get reported on the test server but usually make it into the live build anyway. Some bugs have been around for years and have never been fixed
voteText: eventually cryptic just gave up trying to fix most of them and either labeled them as "working as intended" like cloak deactivating on dialogue popups
helpfulPercent: or just decided to ignore them. This is compounded by the fact that all of the original devs either quit or were let go and the new ones have little knowledge of how the game's base code works. One of them even posted in a forum topic about bugs that "working on STO was like trying to untangle spaghetti
votesHelpful: you're going to end up with a mess no matter what you do."\n\nPower creep has gotten so disgusting in STO that it's even hard for the devs to keep up with it. One of the most popular queued missions (Crystalline cataclysm advanced) has been broken because player damage output can get so high the boss with hundreds of millions of HP sometimes dies before one of the objectives can be completed. A lot of people just shrug and say "oh well"
votesTotal: but when you consider that the objectives are tied to events that trigger at certain HP threshholds and it often dies before the first one finishes so the second one can trigger.....yeah. But instead of addressing the runaway damage output it gets buffed even more? It used to only be the hardcore elite players that could hit the 75k DPS mark
commentsCount: now they're pushing 150k and people hitting 50-75k is becoming common. Instead of giving enemies better AI and more skills to use to mitigate or heal damage cryptic takes the lazy route and just increases HP and damage output for them
column16: then puts out the next set of shinies to boost player damage output and the cycle repeats.\n\nThe game was fun while Atari owned it
column17: and still was for a while after
column18: but it's been turned into just another cash cow that milks a popular franchise. There is very little "Star Trek" material in the game in it's current state aside from the general theme
column19: if the ships and outfits were replaced with generic designs nobody would be able to tell it was a Star Trek themed game. There's no exploration (there actually was an exploration system but it was removed because cryptic decided it would be too much work to update it) and the theme to every mission is "kill them all"
column20: there's no diplomacy options that actually matter (there USED to be diplomacy missions and even first contacts with minor species
column21: but they were removed for the same reason as exploration) since no matter what dialogue choices you make you don't affect the outcome of missions at all
column22: it's basically just flavor text with no substance. The only reason I still play occasionally is I've invested too much time into it to throw it all away
column23:
so I log in every now and then to blow things up for a bit or chat with friends.

TL;DR:
If you think you'd like a generic grind MMO with a Star Trek flavor you may enjoy it
column24: but if you're a Trek fan who's looking for a Star Trek themed MMO
column25: sadly this isn't it."

reviewText:
I know I don't really have the hours recorded on steam but I played this game for a year or two before the Romulan expansion, the community was great, including the resident troll named Butts :) (I have to admit, his trolling was kind of endearing and I kind of miss the way they trolled it had a semblance of respect for people who weren't butt hurt about it LOL).

Also, I've played twoother PWI games, Forsaken World and Perfect World and yes, in some of these games you CAN earn currency to buy what the P2W players buy BUT it's going to take you forever and a year to actually get the currency all the while P2Ws are kicking your ♥♥♥ everywhere in PvP, superior gems and the like.

My very first review, here we go:

The Good:

- The Community was great- Very friendly even if I wasn't a Trekkie.
- The ship fighting was great, I loved every minute of it. (Buff, buff, buff, Guns to lower shields. projectile to destroy the hull, cloak, rinse and repeat)
- The character customization had a lot of options. (What I thought was tanned was actually kind of Orange LOL)
- The missions were also pretty great, just the right amount of challenge.
- The inside of the ships were magnificent.
- Pet Varens in one of the ships.
- Space and ship graphics were good.
- And holy ♥♥♥♥, your guild house is a massive space ship/station, that is all.

The Bad:

- The non-ship combat was clunky. (Clunky drop kick was my favorite thing.)
- The grinding was just... Mind numbing.
- Character graphics looked weirdly like rubber.
- The physics for out of ship combat was weird.

The Ugly:

- PWI's Free-to-play but pay-to-win scheme.

Would I recommend this game? The honest answer is yes, it's a good game and if you have money to spare or parents who can spot for your game cards then why not buy a few account upgrades or IRL cash ships. If you're into the long term grinding experience then you can eventually buy ships that are decent with in-game currency. Yes, you can complete the game without shelling out cash except for buying the DLCs.

Do I hate the PWI experience? A little bit, yes.

Will I not recommend this game simply because it's a PWI game? No, the game deserves it's praise and it's time, Cryptic made this game, not PWI. PWI is simply milking the game for all it's worth because they're a business and that's how they choose to run things.

reviewText:
Fun game (mostly - apart from elements influenced by the cash shop) but by far the worst customer service you'll find.

All up I would have spent a bit over $300 on the lifetime sub and various ships. But when my main character became really badly bugged, affecting something I had spent money on in the cash shop - and it was affecting other players too - could I get them to fix it?

No.

I bugrepped it. Months went by. Nothing. I bugrepped it again. Waited again. Nothing. So I lodged a ticket with customer service. After jumping through hoops (taking screenshots etc.) to prove there was a problem they told me they couldn't fix it and I should bugrep it. Which I'd done. They also specifically told me never to contact CS again about this problem or any like it.

Email records from CS were produced.

So nearly a year later I lodge a complaint with BBB. PWE's initial response was dishonest - saying I should have contacted CS, as if I hadn't. They then ignored BBB's attempts to follow up with them for several months until they gave up and advised me to lodge a complaint with the US Federal Trade Commission.

Meanwhile in their forums, their head of community relations took to slagging me off and perfectly innocent posts of mine were being moderated away. And their developers tried to make me out to be unco-operative, when I had been anything but.

Eventually in the thread about this bug I told them about BBB's advice to complain to the US FTC. Voila! The bug was fixed fixed. That's all it takes to get bugs fixed in this game. A year of bug reporting, CS tickets, complaints to consumer groups and threatening them with an FTC complaint.

I had played and enjoyed the game for a very long time (outside Steam), and spent a lot of money on it, but when a company behaves like this - well no game is worth that. Plus given how aggressive and dishonest they were in relation to the BBB complaint and in their forum, I could never trust that they wouldn't mess with my characters.

Steer clear.

reviewText:
Played a tonne of this just after it went F2P and before it went on Steam.

Really enjoyable space combat game combined with a pretty lackluster ground combat portion. The story missions are pretty enjoyable compared to most MMO's, and make you feel involved in the plot rather than just as a witness to it. Also unlike other MMOs you aren't stuck doing gathering/kill quests to advance, but instead you are doing stuff to advance storylines. It was refreshing to play through an MMO that felt more like a proper story-based game.

At times it feels like a strange fanfic of what happens next in the original universe, but it's still Star Trek. Sure the DS9 and Voyager continuations can make little sense, but it's still a fun time to see those characters return.

If you're a Star Trek fan there is more than enough in here to delight you for a good long while.

reviewText: Over all enjoy this game. Unlike other MMORPG's there is a special feature in this game where players can create their own custom content. This is in the form of maps and missions. With in these there are missions or goals, tho the rewards for these games are standardised by STO (star trek online). If your a fan of star trek online then you'll more than likely enjoy the game for a long time. For even beginers (F2P Free 2 play), there is enough slots open to play 1 character from each faction. With in the game you have choices of engineering, tactical, and science captain. There are similar ships to choose from with appropreate abilities. If you want a little compairison, think of tactical like a fighter, engineer like support/aid/tank (not as high dps as tactical), and science to be along the lines of support ability wizard/cleric (offencive/defencive) Most of the game is available to play for free. In fact you can level up to the maximum level and pilot some top end ships. However special or eliet type ships are much mroe time consuming to get. There are story lines for federation, klingon, and romulan factions (playable). Then as you level up there are chapters about older star trek oddities like tribbles. Missions with the actual Warf as a voice actor. Borg missions, species 8572, volcan, and much more. My personal favoret is to visit deep space 9, Earth space dock, and to fly around where ever I want. I think this game as at least compairable to most other mmorpgs with pets, quests, items, character customization is far supperior than most. There is a lot of content that is available to those willing to spend the money to get it. Rather than monthly subscriptions there are free to play accounts, Monthly subscribers, and life time memberships.  The Life time member enjoy certain rewards and perks continuesly while other perks become available immediately on purchase.

reviewText:
Ah Star Trek, if Starwars is a clut leader in home made robes with a panchant for orgys then Trek is the Vatigan, quite possibly as many orgies and they have all your cash and a swanky place to live to boot...

...wait where was I?

Oh yes Star trek: Online, have you ever wanted to get your hands on the Enterprise?...yea me too but tough luck you cant but you CAN get hold of a ship exactly like it and use it to do pretty much whatever the hell you want! its a massive power trip for all trek fans to swing yourself into the captains chair and let fly with phasers and photon torpedo's into the unsuspecting face of the enemies of the Federation...or the Klingon defence force...or the Romulan republic.

Did i mention its not just limited to the Federation at all? well its not, fancy flying mobiles of every flavour are yours to enjoy as well as every species in the entirity of the franchise and if thats ot quite good enough you can always make a species entirly of your own..y'know if catgirls, klingons, Remans, orions and Ferengi etc. dont take your fancy.

I will admit that the ground combat is a little lacking and some missions feel more than a little grindy" but this is an MMO after all and the space combat generly makes up for it.

Despite the limited time i had the game on steam i have played the game from Beta on its own client and even paied a sub at first
recommended: and with the development of the overhanging plot ripe for the picking and deep connections to bothe the old trek and new as well as each mission feeling a lot like a trek episode this game becomes a must have for anyonr following the canon.\n\noh yes the game IS canon

reviewText:
This game was a guilty pleasure.  I'm a secret Trek nerdo, and I loved the single player aspect.  All the Starfleet line was pretty great, when it wasn't Voyager stuff.  Sorry, Voyager.  The end of the progression has you kind of just doing the same few missions over and over for tier upgrades, that wasn't so great.

It was very pretty and I liked being my special snowflake captain of ships from Miranda to Ridiculous Class.  It is an enjoyable ride if you're looking to free play, but I'm sure you could buy a CE of this game for a dollar off ebay these days and redeem it for some of the better rewards.

Somehow fun despite all of its setbacks.

reviewText: Great game for a Trekky Fan like me. It had a bit of a steep learning curve for me (mainly because I had no other prior MMO experience) but I enjoyed it form the beginning. The universe is vast and filled with stuff to do. The game is FTP but real money can be used to purchase in game goods. Many references are made to the various Star Trek TV series which gives the game a great back-story. Those who play the game without first experiencing the Star Trek universe may or may not like it as the graphics leave something to be desired. Also the game has gliched on me form time to time. In spite of this I still thoroughly enjoy the game and recommend to anyone who is interested that they at least give it a go.

reviewText: If you are a Star Trek fan, you owe it to yourself to give this game a try... for free. It tends to lose itself in the background noise of every other MMO around. It does nothing really special, but it is fun to try to design your own ship and uniforms, and pick your own crew. The only real criticism of this game is the same that I have of every MMO: you are not unique. You have the same gear, access to the same missions, and are captain of a starship just like every other player. Areas around planets and space stations are clogged with dozens of starships, all captained by players. I feel this is evidence of a systemic assumption in MMO design, that players don't want to work for anything. I feel it would have been far more compelling if they required you to work up to being a captian with your own ship.\nFrom a technical standpoint, I have constant issues with the servers being down. I often get significant lag followed by the termination of my connection and (when I try to log back on) the server is down. This is not an occasional thing. Just about every time I sit down to play. I'm pretty positive this is not an issue on my end, as I don't encounter this problem anywhere else. As a result, I've not been able to play this game as much as I'd like.\nOver all, I think it has some value in the idea that you get to see a lot of cool Star Trek stuff. And, if played for free, this can be worth while (and the reason for my recommendation). But I wouldn't pay for a rather bland game with so many server issues.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
My opinion? I would say about 7/10.

First, as a Trek fan I enjoy that it continues the story of the Prime universe, and that there are tons of call backs, references, and even cameos.

Now, when I started, I admittedly felt like the controls were a tad awkward, but once I got used to them. I've found that that's all I really needed: to get used to them.

The space combat is highly reminicent of what's seen in the shows/movies, even including attacks/abilities that can be traced to commands given by the various captains across the generations.

The ground combat/missions could be better, but I personally find them tolerable.

The graphics are good, but not fantastic, and it tells a good story overall.

Also, if you love the ability to customize virtually everything(no, that's not an exageration), you'll get a kick out of this game. You can customize your outfits, your ships(with some restrictions based ship's class/type etc), alter your bridge officers, and even create your own species.

The crafting system is a bit tedious, and materials are hard to come by, but it's not horrible.

Now, if I had to name my biggest issue with this game, its the same as most MMOs: the microtransactions. By using real money to by 'Zen'(100 Zen = $1), you can unlock a lot of stuff, but some of it is kinda petty and/or overpriced. For example if you want to get a new ship past level 50(that's appropriate to your level), you better be willing to pay out $25 PER SHIP. Granted,, there are other ways to secure new level appropriate ships, but most are geared for LV 50, and require grinding for special currencies to aquire.

Also, I have to say I've notice the community tends to be a bit juvenile.  Even though there do appear to be some more mature people among the community, by and large I would recommend just soloing unless you really need help.

So, overall the gameplay is enjoyable and good for Trek fans, plus it also has some good storytelling and decent graphics. But, the petty money stuff and largely immature community are a bit offputting.

If you are a Trek fan, or just love MMOs with lots of customization and decent story, check it out, and enjoy some nostalgia.

If you aren't a Trek fan, can't stand stupid players, or hate microtransactions...feel free to give it a try, but it may not be for you.

reviewText: It certainly has it's weak points; repetetive missions, occasional bugs and some poor gameplay, although that's confined to ground missions. reviewText:
Star Trek has always been a dream MMO for me to play and when I first saw this I knew I had found my one home on the internet.

I installed it and created my account and I was truly amazed by just the amount of immersion they have built into the game. Ypou start by creating your character, You can choose between Federation, Klingon Empire or Romulan Empire... I picked Starfleet of course!

Upon creating your character I was expecting your normal 6 races that were peoples most favs but I soon learned that you could go as far as being Andorian and even a Trill(Joined or not) BUT it does not stop there, They have also included the tools to create your own Alien Race complete with special abilities custom looks and the lot. Imagine Spore Creature Creator in an MMO!

The Tutorial began and I was celebrating graduation from starfleet Academy which for me was a real shame because I would liked to have spent some more time and perhaps even my first 10 levels just learning about the game and the Star Trek Universe. I mean would you take up the chance to do a class on Warp Engineering?

This is where the excittment stopped for me, There is ground combat but I refuse to even Awknowledge that part of the game as its severly lacking in every possible way. (I remember one time I was being chased around a tree by a Klingon... all my friends just stood and laughed at me)

Space battles are extremely intense and provide a great bit of stress relief though I felt there could have been a little more.

SUGGESTION: Not something I can really complaoin about but I'm going to rant and suggest it here... this is Star Trek and there is no ability to command your ship from the captains chair... I want to be able to walk around my ship issuing commands to my crew, not steering and fighting in 3rd person from outside the ship!


Now that is all I can say but would like to also note it is a Theme Park MMO and I find these rather boring so this is not one I have played a lot of but it is one that has earnt itself a spot on my shelf and it will remain there defiantly.

reviewText:
So... how do i explain the game situation... hmmm... Well... roleplaying here is very nice. The lvling up is easy until lvl 50, after that you grind alot to lvl 60. The PVP and PVE lost the strategy. The game is now DPS (Damage Per Second) dependent. For you to get a good build, either you grind alot or you use real money as shortcut. Some ships and consoles from previous events cannot be claimed by players that didnt participate in those events. Special Uniforms and Ships are only caracter unlock, not account-wide (C-Store Uniforms and ships are account-wide).

Why i recomend it?

I just play the game because i like roleplay, i like to grind at the sound of Suicide Mission or The End Run, i like the advanced tailor customization, i like the part where you name your ship anything you want (with the typical restrains like profany)

reviewText: Space, the final frontier. These are the voyages of you, your crew, and your starship. Your ongoing mission; to explore strange new worlds. To seek out new life, and new civilizations. TO BOLDLY GO WHERE NO ONE HAS GONE BEFORE!\n\nThis mmo set several years after the events of the amazing TV series puts you into the Star Trek universe, where you create your captain, pick your crew and pilot your own starship across the cosmos as a member of Starfleet, the Klingon Defense Force, or the Romulan Empire. Explore new systems, sign treaties and decimate your enemies while piloting your favorite ships from series and customizing them to your own accord. The gameplay starts off a little slow, sense you start off with the worst ship in the game and then end up fighting the strongest enemy in the Star Trek universe just in the tutorial alone (in the Starfleet storyline anyway) but as you level up, grab some upgrades, comission new bridge officers and then acquire better starships it gets REALLY REALLY FUN. Plus, the PvE is also the absolute best of any mmo I've ever played.

reviewText: Star Trek Online, or STO, is a game set in the space age with giant ships, a whole selection of races (Not Racing) and a vast galaxy to explore! I will recomend this to people who like Star Trek and to people who don't really know anything about it as through the story telling you will get to grips with basics of Star Trek knowledge. This game is still being updated regulary and has seasonal and daily events that add hours of gameplay added onto the 100+ hours of storyline, side quests and PvP. As this is a Cryptic game the customization is superb from the ships you fly to the crew who fly it. Now this game plays in two ways, one way is with your ship and the other is on the ground. As this is a mmorpg you can get together and play with your friends and play through the missions together or you can play on your own. This game is completely different to other popular mmorpg's as this brings another aspect to the gameplay as it's not just a grind fest on the ground but in space with a whole galaxy to explore meeting different races and player along the way. Now when you start the game you can pick from 3 main races, Starfleet, Klingon and Romulan all having different quests, ships, planets, weapons, armors and gameplay styles so they all offer a different way to play. Now as this game is made by Cryptic it does have some Pay to Win ascpects or in this case pay to unlock before unlocking as about 60% of the items and ships you can get from the 2 non payed currency, zen being the payed one.\n\nI am going to give this game a 8/10 as it has 100's of hours of gameplay, regular updates and a vast community; but let down by its small glitches.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
An all around good game in many ways. First off you have three factions, all with at least a few races in each. Both ground and space combat are solid however space combat is easily the better of the two. There is of course the Federation, the Klingons, and the newest faction which are the Romulans.

The Romulans have a story of liberation and resistance against a nearly rogue sect of the now shattered Romulan Star Empire. You fly warbirds which at each new rank grant you a new ability only usable on warbirds. All of them can cloak and a later version can even split into two.

The downfall of the Romulans in my eye is that they have no great massive ship of their own. I find the Ha'apax Advanced Warbird a bit lacking in that department. And even though you are in fact forced to join either the Federation or Klingons you cannot actually gain access to their T4 and higher ships. So I must recommend a mightier faction, one of glory and honor. The Klingon Empire.

The Klingon story is far more diverse and even includes a small portion of the Romulan story, even including the Romulan end mission around lv32. The story ranges from house rivalries and betrayals to the return of Klingon enemies from ancient lore among other interesting developments. The Klingons are a faction with many mighty ships designed for head-on combat that have hull strength only rivaled by ships you'd have to spend $150 opening gambling boxes to get your hands on. And this does not even diminish their offensive capabilities as their greatest ship is a carrier armed just as well as any warship.

The Fedration offers little that can compare to the might of the Klingon Empire. Their ships seem to be designed around a doctrine of agility as many of their ships are far smaller but probably just as effective in combat if used properly.

There is also a system for crew missions, where you deploy your crew to go do things like sacking a colony, bribery, espionage, fighting in tournaments, trade agreements, asteroid mining for arguably the most valuable currency dilithium, among other tasks. These all net rewards which vary by the rarity of the mission, its difficulty, who's on it, and of course what the mission is in the first place determines the base set of rewards. You can even send one of your crew to be executed for incompetence as a Klingon, which even though its useless is just great to have sitting there as an option.

The visuals are good, the game hasn't crashed once for me, the UI is customizable.

All in all, a great MMO.

reviewText:
Having played this game since release, Feb 2010. I love it and still do.  I've played lots of different titles that have been licensed with the 'Star Trek' IP, this game is probably the best one because it's pretty close to the universe that has been established by the various films and series.  Trust me... I've played plenty of the other trek games which have been very poorly implemented and are buggy... *cough* Star Trek: Armada *cough*

To absolute trekkies, this game gives plenty of 'nods' to all of the series such as Planets, ship systems, characters, races and many more.

To give a balanced view of the game, I must say that the lockbox side of the game isn't in the spirit of the trek universe but I understand that Cryptic have to make money to keep this game going to keep publishing new content and refreshing older content... if they don't, it'll go the way of WoW and become stagnant.

reviewText: Space, the final frontier. These are the voyages of you, your crew, and your starship. Your ongoing mission; to explore strange new worlds. To seek out new life, and new civilizations. TO BOLDLY GO WHERE NO ONE HAS GONE BEFORE!\n\nThis mmo set several years after the events of the amazing TV series puts you into the Star Trek universe, where you create your captain, pick your crew and pilot your own starship across the cosmos as a member of Starfleet, the Klingon Defense Force, or the Romulan Empire. Explore new systems, sign treaties and decimate your enemies while piloting your favorite ships from series and customizing them to your own accord. The gameplay starts off a little slow, sense you start off with the worst ship in the game and then end up fighting the strongest enemy in the Star Trek universe just in the tutorial alone (in the Starfleet storyline anyway) but as you level up, grab some upgrades, comission new bridge officers and then acquire better starships it gets REALLY REALLY FUN. Plus, the PvE is also the absolute best of any mmo I've ever played.

reviewText:
I haven't played Star Trek Online since it launched back in February of 2010. I can say without a doubt that I was excited for this game when I first pre-ordered it. And then I played it. It wasn't the worst MMO I had ever played but it definitely didn't live up to my expectations. The ground combat was clunky, the early story and missions were boring and there was little to no voice acting. About the only thing I did like was the ship to ship combat. But that couldn't save it for me. I just couldn't bring myself to buy the full version.

Now, 4 years later, I find myself picking it up again after hearing about how many changes have been made. It piqued my curiosity so I began to play last week. Trust me when I say, this isn't the same game that I decided against buying 4 years ago. Pretty much everything has been revamped. The game is now in it's 8th major update since launch, so there's quite a bit of new content.

Starting out, the first thing I noticed that the whole intro has been scrapped and is now completely different. Instead of finding yourself in the middle of a Borg attack, you are now an Ensign at Starfleet Academy, who has just graduated and been given his (or her) first assignment. You have been chosen to be the First Officer aboard a not-so-new Miranda Class ship. Your first mission is to go out and collect some data samples with your cadet crew. Then things go wrong.

The story is engrossing from the very first moments. It's a major step up from what used to be.

Then there's the C-Store. Currently, the game is Free To Play, which is good for someone like me, who's on a budget. Usually I hate the Free to Play options in games because I feel like my version is severely diminished. That's not the case in Star Trek Online. As a matter of fact, aside from some nifty cosmetic stuff and things like different styles of ships, I haven't really seen anything different between the Free to Play stuff and Paid subscribers. There are a few things, such as more costume slots or extra Duty Officers, which are nice but not necessarily hindering you if you don't have them.

What really impresses me about the C-Store is the ability to buy Zen (the currency used in the Cash Shop) with in-game Dilithium. Admittedly, it's at a pretty steep cost. About 125 Dilithium per 1 Zen. That means that if you want to buy the cheapest item in the C-Store, you'll need about 31,000 Dilithium saved up. Which is going to take you quite a bit of grinding. But still. The option is there and that's more than most other games will give you.

Overall, I have been having a blast. Currently I've only made it to Level 20 (Commander) and I have yet to join a Fleet but that hasn't stopped the fun from rolling in.

The only thing I could really ask for is some good PVP or better PVE Instance queues. But that's not to say I wont keep playing.

At the moment, I am going to give it a 7 out of 10. I've seen some bugs but those are nothing that can't be fixed in later patches.

reviewText: Star Trek Online, or STO, is a game set in the space age with giant ships, a whole selection of races (Not Racing) and a vast galaxy to explore! I will recomend this to people who like Star Trek and to people who don't really know anything about it as through the story telling you will get to grips with basics of Star Trek knowledge. This game is still being updated regulary and has seasonal and daily events that add hours of gameplay added onto the 100+ hours of storyline, side quests and PvP. As this is a Cryptic game the customization is superb from the ships you fly to the crew who fly it. Now this game plays in two ways, one way is with your ship and the other is on the ground. As this is a mmorpg you can get together and play with your friends and play through the missions together or you can play on your own. This game is completely different to other popular mmorpg's as this brings another aspect to the gameplay as it's not just a grind fest on the ground but in space with a whole galaxy to explore meeting different races and player along the way. Now when you start the game you can pick from 3 main races, Starfleet, Klingon and Romulan all having different quests, ships, planets, weapons, armors and gameplay styles so they all offer a different way to play. Now as this game is made by Cryptic it does have some Pay to Win ascpects or in this case pay to unlock before unlocking as about 60% of the items and ships you can get from the 2 non payed currency, zen being the payed one.\n\nI am going to give this game a 8/10 as it has 100's of hours of gameplay, regular updates and a vast community; but let down by its small glitches.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
An all around good game in many ways. First off you have three factions, all with at least a few races in each. Both ground and space combat are solid however space combat is easily the better of the two. There is of course the Federation, the Klingons, and the newest faction which are the Romulans.

The Romulans have a story of liberation and resistance against a nearly rogue sect of the now shattered Romulan Star Empire. You fly warbirds which at each new rank grant you a new ability only usable on warbirds. All of them can cloak and a later version can even split into two.

The downfall of the Romulans in my eye is that they have no great massive ship of their own. I find the Ha'apax Advanced Warbird a bit lacking in that department. And even though you are in fact forced to join either the Federation or Klingons you cannot actually gain access to their T4 and higher ships. So I must recommend a mightier faction, one of glory and honor. The Klingon Empire.

The Klingon story is far more diverse and even includes a small portion of the Romulan story, even including the Romulan end mission around lv32. The story ranges from house rivalries and betrayals to the return of Klingon enemies from ancient lore among other interesting developments. The Klingons are a faction with many mighty ships designed for head-on combat that have hull strength only rivaled by ships you'd have to spend $150 opening gambling boxes to get your hands on. And this does not even diminish their offensive capabilities as their greatest ship is a carrier armed just as well as any warship.

The Fedration offers little that can compare to the might of the Klingon Empire. Their ships seem to be designed around a doctrine of agility as many of their ships are far smaller but probably just as effective in combat if used properly.

There is also a system for crew missions, where you deploy your crew to go do things like sacking a colony, bribery, espionage, fighting in tournaments, trade agreements, asteroid mining for arguably the most valuable currency dilithium, among other tasks. These all net rewards which vary by the rarity of the mission, its difficulty, who's on it, and of course what the mission is in the first place determines the base set of rewards. You can even send one of your crew to be executed for incompetence as a Klingon, which even though its useless is just great to have sitting there as an option.

The visuals are good, the game hasn't crashed once for me, the UI is customizable.

All in all, a great MMO.

reviewText: Simply put, Star Trek Online is a wonderful game.  You are given a high level of customization over your characters, crew, uniforms, weapons, and ships.  While you can spend money on items, simple Dilithium mining, grinding, and ship-to-ship combat can provide most of the currency needed to buy items.  Larger battles can provide all manner of weapons and ship upgrades you can sell, equip, or trade.  Story writing is excellent and puts you in several famous locations throughout the galaxy.  If you are a Star Trek fan open to playing in MMORPG, this is the game for you!!!

reviewText: Over all enjoy this game. Unlike other MMORPG's there is a special feature in this game where players can create their own custom content. This is in the form of maps and missions. With in these there are missions or goals, tho the rewards for these games are standardised by STO (star trek online). If your a fan of star trek online then you'll more than likely enjoy the game for a long time. For even beginers (F2P Free 2 play), there is enough slots open to play 1 character from each faction. With in the game you have choices of engineering, tactical, and science captain. There are similar ships to choose from with appropreate abilities. If you want a little compairison, think of tactical like a fighter, engineer like support/aid/tank (not as high dps as tactical), and science to be along the lines of support ability wizard/cleric (offencive/defencive) Most of the game is available to play for free. In fact you can level up to the maximum level and pilot some top end ships. However special or eliet type ships are much mroe time consuming to get. There are story lines for federation, klingon, and romulan factions (playable). Then as you level up there are chapters about older star trek oddities like tribbles. Missions with the actual Warf as a voice actor. Borg missions, species 8572, volcan, and much more. My personal favoret is to visit deep space 9, Earth space dock, and to fly around where ever I want. I think this game as at least compairable to most other mmorpgs with pets, quests, items, character customization is far supperior than most. There is a lot of content that is available to those willing to spend the money to get it. Rather than monthly subscriptions there are free to play accounts, Monthly subscribers, and life time memberships.  The Life time member enjoy certain rewards and perks continuesly while other perks become available immediately on purchase.

reviewText:
**REVIEW POST UPDATE 7/20/2014 6:46 PM (PDT)**
A few months have passed, and so many new things came to the STO Universe. Such as more inventory space for free, and bank space. We are currently in Season 9.5 A New Accord. The .5 generally brings some modifications to game performance and what not. We should expect some new things, in Season 10. For now however, I have been exploring the STO Universe, making new friends, discovering new things, and more! I still do greatly recommend the game, for newcomers to STO, you guys get an updated Tutorial :3, but have fun, and never give up!

*REVIEW POST UPDATE 4/6/2014 1:12 PM (PST)*
The game has greatly improved over the past year that I had been playing it. Although, the Dyson Sphere can use some work, as there is a huge bug where the ground below you spazzes out, but other than that, a very great game. You might see other people that are Vice Admiral(Level 50 [Max Player Level]) and might make fun of you or something related, just ignore them. There are very few Vice Admirals' out there that would help newcomers into the STO Universe. I became one of these people and help any newcomer that I see that is in trouble, when it comes to a mission, friendly stroll in Sector Space, or some casual talk. I think every newcomer into the STO Universe, should remember one thing, Never give up.

What you see there, was something I learned when ranking up within STO. If you need any help, low level or not, you can always message me In-Game(If online), or send me a Friend Request through Steam, message me and I will get back to you ASAP. I really care to help out newcomers into the STO Universe, it's a really fun and addicting game. So just download the game, and come on and join us!

reviewText: This is probably the only free to play MMO that has managed to keep me playing for more a couple of weeks.  The story is engaging for Star Trek fans.  The space combat can be quite complex and is one of the most addicting parts of the game.  Ground combat is somewhat lacking, in my opinion, but not enough not to play it.  Even at the level cap (50) I find plenty to keep me engaged.  The Dyson Sphere, Romulan, Borg, and Undine stories will have you entertained for hours.  I can't recommend this enough.  Don't let the cash shop fool you.  The game is not pay-to-win.  There are some unique weapons there, but they aren't any more powerful than other items you can get through missions.  Download this and give it a go.  You won't regret it.

reviewText: If you are a Star Trek fan, you owe it to yourself to give this game a try... for free. It tends to lose itself in the background noise of every other MMO around. It does nothing really special, but it is fun to try to design your own ship and uniforms, and pick your own crew. The only real criticism of this game is the same that I have of every MMO: you are not unique. You have the same gear, access to the same missions, and are captain of a starship just like every other player. Areas around planets and space stations are clogged with dozens of starships, all captained by players. I feel this is evidence of a systemic assumption in MMO design, that players don't want to work for anything. I feel it would have been far more compelling if they required you to work up to being a captian with your own ship.\nFrom a technical standpoint, I have constant issues with the servers being down. I often get significant lag followed by the termination of my connection and (when I try to log back on) the server is down. This is not an occasional thing. Just about every time I sit down to play. I'm pretty positive this is not an issue on my end, as I don't encounter this problem anywhere else. As a result, I've not been able to play this game as much as I'd like.\nOver all, I think it has some value in the idea that you get to see a lot of cool Star Trek stuff. And, if played for free, this can be worth while (and the reason for my recommendation). But I wouldn't pay for a rather bland game with so many server issues.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
My opinion? I would say about 7/10.

First, as a Trek fan I enjoy that it continues the story of the Prime universe, and that there are tons of call backs, references, and even cameos.

Now, when I started, I admittedly felt like the controls were a tad awkward, but once I got used to them. I've found that that's all I really needed: to get used to them.

The space combat is highly reminicent of what's seen in the shows/movies, even including attacks/abilities that can be traced to commands given by the various captains across the generations.

The ground combat/missions could be better, but I personally find them tolerable.

The graphics are good, but not fantastic, and it tells a good story overall.

Also, if you love the ability to customize virtually everything(no, that's not an exageration), you'll get a kick out of this game. You can customize your outfits, your ships(with some restrictions based ship's class/type etc), alter your bridge officers, and even create your own species.

The crafting system is a bit tedious, and materials are hard to come by, but it's not horrible.

Now, if I had to name my biggest issue with this game, its the same as most MMOs: the microtransactions. By using real money to by 'Zen'(100 Zen = $1), you can unlock a lot of stuff, but some of it is kinda petty and/or overpriced. For example if you want to get a new ship past level 50(that's appropriate to your level), you better be willing to pay out $25 PER SHIP. Granted,, there are other ways to secure new level appropriate ships, but most are geared for LV 50, and require grinding for special currencies to aquire.

Also, I have to say I've notice the community tends to be a bit juvenile.  Even though there do appear to be some more mature people among the community, by and large I would recommend just soloing unless you really need help.

So, overall the gameplay is enjoyable and good for Trek fans, plus it also has some good storytelling and decent graphics. But, the petty money stuff and largely immature community are a bit offputting.

If you are a Trek fan, or just love MMOs with lots of customization and decent story, check it out, and enjoy some nostalgia.

If you aren't a Trek fan, can't stand stupid players, or hate microtransactions...feel free to give it a try, but it may not be for you.

reviewText:
There's a lot of stuff to say about STO.

First of all, it's absolutely huge, the story alone lasts for many hours already, and the content is constantly being expanded, partially even with things like player created missions. I like Star Trek a little in general but I never was a big fan of the series or anything like that.
The graphics in the game are generally pretty good in my opinion, and some of the systems (like the fluidic space) are actually eye candy. The character customisation is pretty cool.

True to a really big MMO there are a lot of places with a lot of things you can do, and it'll take a hundred hours or so just to try everything out.

I'll save myself listing Pros and Cons, as enough reviews have already done that.

Also, beware of the Gorn jokes.

reviewText:
Star Trek has always been a dream MMO for me to play and when I first saw this I knew I had found my one home on the internet.

I installed it and created my account and I was truly amazed by just the amount of immersion they have built into the game. Ypou start by creating your character, You can choose between Federation, Klingon Empire or Romulan Empire... I picked Starfleet of course!

Upon creating your character I was expecting your normal 6 races that were peoples most favs but I soon learned that you could go as far as being Andorian and even a Trill(Joined or not) BUT it does not stop there, They have also included the tools to create your own Alien Race complete with special abilities custom looks and the lot. Imagine Spore Creature Creator in an MMO!

The Tutorial began and I was celebrating graduation from starfleet Academy which for me was a real shame because I would liked to have spent some more time and perhaps even my first 10 levels just learning about the game and the Star Trek Universe. I mean would you take up the chance to do a class on Warp Engineering?

This is where the excittment stopped for me, There is ground combat but I refuse to even Awknowledge that part of the game as its severly lacking in every possible way. (I remember one time I was being chased around a tree by a Klingon... all my friends just stood and laughed at me)

Space battles are extremely intense and provide a great bit of stress relief though I felt there could have been a little more.

SUGGESTION: Not something I can really complaoin about but I'm going to rant and suggest it here... this is Star Trek and there is no ability to command your ship from the captains chair... I want to be able to walk around my ship issuing commands to my crew, not steering and fighting in 3rd person from outside the ship!


Now that is all I can say but would like to also note it is a Theme Park MMO and I find these rather boring so this is not one I have played a lot of but it is one that has earnt itself a spot on my shelf and it will remain there defiantly.

reviewText:
TL;DR?
Go play SWTOR.  Same damn game, less ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.


I do not recommend this title AT ALL.  Trolls run free through the game, harassing roleplayers AND taking fleets (imagine a guild where you have to spend thousands of man-hours building the guild's home) from the other players.  Beside that, Cryptic, the original owner, were bought out by perfect world.  Items which were originally affordable through the dilithium-FreemiumBucks exchange are no longer, so it's impossible to get any new clothing that has come out since launch for free.  Most new, pretty ships are horribly over priced.  Don't ever expect to get the best stuff in this game.

Next, the gameplay.  Gawd the gameplay.  Imagine, if you will, a Star Trek.. that has nothing to do with Star Trek.  We're not talking 2009 the video game here!  I mean this game has nothing to do with star trek 9/10ths the time.  If I weren't green, I'd think I was in a totally different game.  Which is forgivable.  That's immersion in other games.  Not here.  Here, the gameplay itself isn't even remotely complimentary to the license.

You get your choice of Science, Tatical, or Engineering officer.  Coolio.  That's fine.  The difference is the powers you can use in the space combat and in the awayteams.  Tatical gets some team buffs for DPS, engineer can create items out of thinair, and science has some stuff such as stasis fields.  That's cool, right?  Nope.  None of that actually solves anything.  You still have to kill the targets to move on.  No diplomacy, no alternate route, you have to murder the NPCs to move on.

Okay, lets move on to out of combat stuff.  WHAT OUT OF COMBAT STUFF?  You'd think you'd get a minigame that's like Oh
date: reallign these chips and then order some members of your crew to replace some plating that got blown off."  Nope.  None of that.  Anytime you get to do anything REMOTELY tech related

reviewText: Surprisingly good. I have not tried PvP, but throughout the PvE/story missions, I have never felt pressured to spend any money on the game. You unlock a new ship every 10 levels, and new ships are occasionally available for free during event missions. Every ingame thing you might need (gear, bridge officers, deck officers) is available from (relatively easily) obtainable resources in game as well as money.  The endgame isn't lacking in PvE, as of this writing there is a battlegrounds area for ground combat, and plenty of task force missions for space combat.\n\nIn summary, the game is worth taking a shot at, even if you aren't a diehard trek fan.

reviewText:
One of the things that has always bugged me about MMOs is the long distance running to turn in quests. First they send you on a stupid quest to exact some justice on some lame fool who did something bad (insert short mission story line here), and when you finally get the guy and retrieve the spoils of battle from his cold dead corpse you have to run for days back to the quest giver to turn the mission in. So, for over an hour of gameplay you actually only played the game for maybe 5 minutes.  Not the case with Star Trek Online.

In this space faring MMO you are the captain of your ship. You get to go out and have adventures and all that of a regular MMO with the flare of Star Trek. Along the way you can meet some characters from the shows. All that is to be expected. What was surprising was they way can get your quests.

Like most MMOs you can walk up to a quest-giver and talk to them and they will give you the quest. In Star Trek Online you have the option of Calling them from your ship and selecting the mission from the list of available missions. It's almost as if the creators knew that you'd be a long, long way out in the middle of nowhere and wouldn't want to continually run back to to them just to turn in a quest. It is Star Trek, after all, why not just put them up on the main screen, Number One, and we can get on with our mission?

Overall the graphics are basic for what systems can pull these days, and the voice acting in ok. The gameplay is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥me so you quest a lot. If you are a fan of Star Trek like me then you can forgive the game a lot and play for fun. At the sweet price of free, you don't even really need to be a fan to try it and see if space adventuring is right for you. Just keep in mind, if you are looking for the next blockbuster MMO to scale the mountain and dares all to knock them off of it, you're looking in the wrong place. This game is made for fun not necessarily to dazzle or impress you.

reviewText:
Personal Rating: 6/10

I've yet to play more of this game and I'm definately looking forward to it. While it is missing some essential characters such as Kirk or Spock, the impeccable voice acting and character emotion is amazing. Naturally, like all MMORPG's there is a lot of collecting x amount of y monster. But it doesn't feel overdone or underdone in this game. I'm not a Star Trek fan but I'm enjoying it! The combat is fluent and the dialogue is near-perfect.

However, there are only two things wrong, small things, but non the less they are essential. The frist point being my character has no voice and for such a star studded audio presentation it deterierates into laughable situations where it's a very serious moment, everybody panicing and there's me, stood there, emotionless and voiceless.

My second and final complaint it the ship. I hate controlling the ship, it just feels clunky and I can never get it to the right speed.

But other than that it's a thoroughly enjoyable game (so far) and I'm looking forward to playing more of it. Unfortunate lack of Simon Pegg though.

reviewText:
STO has been my game of choice since participating in the closed beta. Though it suffered from a difficult start and bumps along the way, the game has continued to evolve and grow. The PvE aspect of the game has become expansive and can seem a bit overwhelming at times for new players. With so many systems integrated over the years from Duty officer missions and abilities, Reputations systems, countless gearsets/combinations, greatly improved crafting system finally in place, and of course the missions both official and player created, the game feels mostly complete and whole finally. Like any MMO it will continue to evolve and not always in a direction everyone will be happy with. That said the Development team generally gets it right. The free to play aspect is among the best I have encountered in all my thirty years as a gamer and the last ten or so with my encounters with free to play models. There are items a player would need to purchase for endgame such as ship upgrade tokens, fleet modules, and a removal of the energy credit cap. All items mentioned can be purchased with either cashy money or in game dillithium converted to game currency through the dillithium exchange.

Now for the bad. The PvP is woefully lacking in improvement and attention since launch. While it can be entertaining the public qeues are so one sided and have been since a few months after launch. Abilities are often unblanaced to a fault. Often you are stuck with either the cookie cutter flavor of the month builds, abilites, Duty officer combinations. Even if you have a great build you can expect to lose unless you have a mostly coordinated team all geared and built to provide the DPS and support needed to win. I would not recommend PvP to any new player without first consulting with a PvP group in game sadly.

As for the bad part of the PvE side, The Special task Force missions and Advanced Qeues have become a DPS race. You need to participate in advanced Qeues to get items needed for reputation gear. Often if you need reputation gear you are not in a position to contribute much to the team. another. Another issues is the complete lack of need for the Enginner and Science professions in game. In space missions and PvP they are vastly less valuable than a Tactical captain because they cannot produce the same kind of DPS. Having had thirty eight Max level characters before Delta Rising and Six after fully geared and tested to a minimum of 15k DPS and some to as high as 35k (Good but far from great measured by the Infected Space Advanced Standard) and often coordinating for PvP and having written a few of the build guides over the years I feel qualified to say this. It is just the nature of the game for now and may change with balancing as time goes on. On a final note for the PvE is a lack of attention to some bugs, though not game breaking, they can be irritating.

All that said if you are still here I completely recommend this game. The good vastly outweighs the bad and I will continue to play so long as this is true. See you out there.

reviewText:
I joined this game only after it transition to the Free-to-play model and am basing this review off of that experience, and is a well above average concept for a free-to-play MMO. With a high production value, quite remarkable music score and high quality dialogue for what little dialogue there is the game feels quite polished to date. For the Starship junkie such as myself, the ships look detailed and true to canon. The main quest is gripping and enjoyable, it makes levelling a breeze with a good balance of investment and reward as your character levels.

In contrast to other free-to-play MMO’s, the micro-transactions in this game are kept to a minimum; most purchases made from the Cash shop are entirely cosmetic, which have little to no impact on game-play, and are not necessary in the progression of your character. In addition to that, the in-game currency Dilithium can be converted to large sums of cash shop credit, offering economical alternatives for those that don’t wish to outlay any cash, but spend vast amounts of time playing.

Space combat is one of its strengths, you will have direct control over your ship and its stations with everything laid-out in front of you. Basic Starship operation and commands are very intuitive with control tight and concise. Yet, ground combat is another story. On the ground, your skills are vastly different from that in space, how effective your combat will be will be dependent on the your chosen away team, with the focus on movement, your equipment and environmental hazards, as well as the groups of varying enemies. Coupled with the rather basic RPG style of button mashing to complete your attach, ground missions will wear out their welcome sooner rather than later.

Space exploration itself is somewhat of a disappointment, for an open-world title, the experience you’ll have amongst the different sectors and its planets are at best, predictable and simple. Most missions comprise of destroying ships or scanning structures. While the strong story arc helps break the monotony and generally tie pieces together, most of the open-world encounters have little to no plot or reward for your time invested.

In comparison to other MMO’s, the amount of content can be scarce, once you have reached your characters level cap and completed the official episodes you will have very little to do, especially if you’re the one to play solo. Playing with a friend or joining a guild will be highly recommended to break the monotony of grinding and the entertainment flowing. While all MMO’s have their fair share of grinding, the problem here is the lack of variety on what to grind at.

For a free-to-play MMO, this game does stand-out amongst the rest. It’s well-polished, true to Star Trek lore and canon and an enjoyable experience within a group, and on the plus side, you get to be a Star Ship Captain. As a relatively high-quality product, it’s the community that will once again let it down. Every on-line game has its fair share of elitists and career orientated players that often need to stop and brush the Dorito crumbs from their neck-beards every once in a while and thankfully the community can be filtered out.

This game mostly focuses on PVE and not PVP (it doesn't mean there is no PVP - just less people play it) and doing missions with your fleet buddies is really fun; or even solo.

reviewText:
I joined this game only after it transition to the Free-to-play model and am basing this review off of that experience, and is a well above average concept for a free-to-play MMO. With a high production value, quite remarkable music score and high quality dialogue for what little dialogue there is the game feels quite polished to date. For the Starship junkie such as myself, the ships look detailed and true to canon. The main quest is gripping and enjoyable, it makes levelling a breeze with a good balance of investment and reward as your character levels.

In contrast to other free-to-play MMO’s, the micro-transactions in this game are kept to a minimum; most purchases made from the Cash shop are entirely cosmetic, which have little to no impact on game-play, and are not necessary in the progression of your character. In addition to that, the in-game currency Dilithium can be converted to large sums of cash shop credit, offering economical alternatives for those that don’t wish to outlay any cash, but spend vast amounts of time playing.

Space combat is one of its strengths, you will have direct control over your ship and its stations with everything laid-out in front of you. Basic Starship operation and commands are very intuitive with control tight and concise. Yet, ground combat is another story. On the ground, your skills are vastly different from that in space, how effective your combat will be will be dependent on the your chosen away team, with the focus on movement, your equipment and environmental hazards, as well as the groups of varying enemies. Coupled with the rather basic RPG style of button mashing to complete your attach, ground missions will wear out their welcome sooner rather than later.

Space exploration itself is somewhat of a disappointment, for an open-world title, the experience you’ll have amongst the different sectors and its planets are at best, predictable and simple. Most missions comprise of destroying ships or scanning structures. While the strong story arc helps break the monotony and generally tie pieces together, most of the open-world encounters have little to no plot or reward for your time invested.

In comparison to other MMO’s, the amount of content can be scarce, once you have reached your characters level cap and completed the official episodes you will have very little to do, especially if you’re the one to play solo. Playing with a friend or joining a guild will be highly recommended to break the monotony of grinding and the entertainment flowing. While all MMO’s have their fair share of grinding, the problem here is the lack of variety on what to grind at.

For a free-to-play MMO, this game does stand-out amongst the rest. It’s well-polished, true to Star Trek lore and canon and an enjoyable experience within a group, and on the plus side, you get to be a Star Ship Captain. As a relatively high-quality product, it’s the community that will once again let it down. Every on-line game has its fair share of elitists and career orientated players that often need to stop and brush the Dorito crumbs from their neck-beards every once in a while and thankfully the community can be filtered out.

reviewText:
Ok so I am a huge huge trekkie and loved this game in 2014. It was awesome to fly these awesome spaceships I grew up watching and walking around on all these different planets and such then.....the newness wore off as you can pretty much make lvl 1-50 1 lvl a mission and you can only replay so many times before it just gets boring. There is alot to do when you first reach max lvl(which is 60 but will take you longer to make 50-60 then 1-50) you have the PvE missions for marks to advance thru your rep systems and crafting and patrols but again after awhile of the same thing every day it gets old I guess but prior to this in Nov of last year I said what the hell and dropped a huge chunk of change to go lifetime as I was liking the game so much and had invested real money for ships and whatnot so it was all good....then.....Delta Rising came out and suddenly everthing was different, they revamped main mobs to make it really hard in the PvE missions to win without dying 30 times which is ok to a point but then people started leaving....and more people....and do not let cryptic fool you STO does not have one of the largest up and coming player bases just the opposite. So, both my fleets (fed and kdf) both crumbled as mass people left the game due to unstabilities, bugs and the fact that it seems the devs are not concerned with fixing the current issues instead, they pump item after item into the zen marketplace (real money) trying to bleed people dry. If you plan to just play here and there and love the sto world then I say go for it but do not look forward to investing your time to make it your primary game however, to each thier own and you like others may not agree with this review and thats cool. Overall, STO is not a wothless game and with over 2k hours I can say I have enjoyed the hell out of it till late and hope that cryptic changes their ways before its too late because I would love to see this game regain its former glory!

SPACE COMBAT: The ships are nice to look at though the fed ships tend to all sort of look the same they are awesome to look at with the renderscale turned up. Combat is functional and easy to pick up using main attacks combined with abilities aquired by different bridge officers. One of the recent changes I do like alot was the ability to train a bridge officer with all the skills they are able to learn and change them on the fly rather than having to have multiple officers with different skills. each shi[ has 4 sided shields guarding its hull unlike eve and whatnot with a single shield that drains from all damage no matter the facing. Groups on the Federation side are still relitivly easy to get for PvE mark missions. I do like how you can go to the bridge of  your ship and look around and on most fed ships can go to the different decks and such.

[u]GROUND COMBAT[/u]: Here I feel there is alot to be improved as you fight either in 3rd person targeting each target manually or you can go to FPS mode by pressing B allowing you to aim and get more involved. there is quite alot of different gear you can equip giving you different abilities and skills. I do feel that there is somthing missing from combat here and it feels kind of rough in fights. There is a battlezone where after 50 I think you can go and fight dino's with lasers and the ability to call down orbital strikes lol but they are fun to fight.

[u]OVERALL[/u]:[b] Until the devs step up and fix some issues and start listening to us the players I can not recomend this game at this time[/b] . Try this game out if you dont plan on spending any money or dont plan on it bieng a primary game, if you are a trekkie you will prolly have some fun at least going and reading the planet lore for system to system : ) . Hope this helped somewhat and hope you have a great day even if you decide not to play!

easy and engaging, with so many side stories to keep you entertained for hours and hours.

two thumbs up to this game
