reviewText:
=========Citizen's Review=========This game is what you expect from a star trek MMO although more combat based.Theres tons of things to do starting off and is generally a good game with Content being added through Seasons.This is one of those games that You have the option to pay to win in,but really thats a personal choice a normal F2P player can get around just fine.Theres 3 factions that you can play as: Federation Klingon and Aligned romulan.Each with their own unique story some of which have voice actors from the orignial Shows.
---------------Factions--------------- Federation is The faction thats The most Story Oriented ,Their ships Nearly all look the same and they have formidible cruisers and nifty Pay ships being the Main faction they have the most ships.
Klingon is The PVP oriented Faction that Is generally about combat (if you know about the lore then you already know this)Their ships Are built for Manuverability and General head on combat with the ability to cloak outside of it.Their endgame Ships are Built for Survivability.
Romulan is the Jack of all trades Faction that has a Good story and Can Side with either of the two factions above.Their ships are Weak starting off but get alot of abilities to compensate,but in the right hands they can be formiddible,Especially if you know what your doing if you decide to pay. Their endgame ships have Countless abilities that can overwelm some people but in the right hands they can be amazing, Being The Head admiral with a Romulan Scimitar Dreadnaught Thats nearly unkillable i can say that it worked out well for me.The only negative Aspect of this game is how repetitive it gets especially at end game where all you do is try to grind marks for the advanced reputation end gear.
---------Clans/Fleets--------- As for clans theres alot of things you can do clan wise which are known as fleets in this game
Fleets are unique in that they have their own Starbase that Players can Contribute to in order for the base to grow.Having multiple Fleet Projects that can upgrade the base in generall and give access to New Gear /Assigments and Income being dilithium Ore,their endgame gear is Extremely powerful and can overshadow some Mark gear if built Correctly.
---------Crafting---------In one of the recent updates a Crafting system was added to the game which allows you to make almost anything you need if you have the materials for it.This is generally usefull if you want to make Ingame currency and generally make your self better.
--------Economics--------Theres 3 Main currency types are EC/Dilithium/Zen Secondary are Fleet Credits
EC is the standard ingame currency thats used for most of the Ingame commerce and Exchange
Dilithium is the Currency thats rewarded for daily activities.It can also be mined through Daily events as well.This is the Currency that can be traded for Premium Currency which is Zen and can be used to obtain the high end fleet gear combined with Fleet Credits.
Zen is the Premium paystore currency that will buy you most of the Ship/items you see in the store it can also be exchanged for massive amounts of Dilithium.
Fleet Credits are what you get for Contributing to Fleet Projects and is what you want if you want the High end fleet Gear and Equipment.
----------Paystore----------The paystore is huge and you will need to pay to get rid of the ingame money limit but thats in every MMO nowadays especially F2P.Most of the best ships ingame can be bought through microtransactions and i know this may seem ugly to some but they need to make money somehow in order to keep making Revenue and running their game, it being attached to the most sucessful show in history this is not suprising on how expensive most things are.The Extremely Unique ships I guess you could say Supporter" ships can be Expensive Some totaling in around 160$ USD to get and this is from combined Lobi crystals from opened lockboxes.Some of these ships have amazing abilities though but ill leave that to you to decide.The normal Endgame ships id say go for about 20$ usd however the higher endgame ships can go for about 30$ each
date:
most of them being the Tier 6 Ships.Some of these can be worth it with Some of the abilities they have but ill leave that to you to decide.
-------------Pros/Cons-------------==Pros== Tons of stuff to do
Both space and ground combat
Clan/Fleet Progression
Some Voice acting
Entertaining combat
Tons of story missions
Star trek lore Everywhere
Great character customization
Decent enough leveling
Good and helpful community in General
Some endgame Reputations Are easy to grind
Can run on almost any PC with as low as 2-4 GB of ram==Cons(For some)==
Very large paystore
Some bugs here and there
Changing UI:Every few updates somthing new gets added that makes the UI alot more Complicated for some people.
Endgame Reputation Grind is painful for some reputations====Extreme Cons/Warnings====  Spammers: Shady Third Party Spammers
recommended: Every so often you will see someone in chat advertising about some website and in some cases even Adding/Spamming/Removing you from their Friends list in order to promote these websites that sell cheap ingame goods at prices that are Heavly Reduced such as Lockbox keys and Founder/Lobi ships.All of these websites are Run by identity theves that just want your Personal info And/Or Account so just ignore them\nSo just take the high route and just ignore them and report them if you do encounter them. ( not like it will do much anyway but still do it  ).\nTLOverall id say this is a Game worth playing even if you arent a Star trek fan its worth giving it a try.and in some cases paying."

reviewText: This game has come a long, long way since I began playing about 3-4 years ago. Back then it was like a hollow shell, filled with boring things to do, not many cool things and mostly it was just kind of bland. Now, however, they've totally revamped the game it's no longer what it used to be. It's fun, engaging, exciting and for us Trekkies (LLAP!   \\//,) it's become the game we all wanted it to be. I highly recommend it for any Sci-fi fan, Trekkie, MMORPG'er or mixed FPS/3rd Person style gamer, it doesnt play like any other game I've played. It has an incredibly versatile battle system for fighting in space and on the ground. They've bulked it up with exsquisitely created fan mods which are stories you can playthrough...basically player created DLC. They've added all kinds of new types of missions: diplomatic, space missions, research missions, ground missions of all sorts, away team missions and lots of sweet new gear to boot. The characters themselves look the best they've ever looked; when I first began playing I was very disappointed in the way they looked, they were all sort of the same looking. Now, the characters have tight gear and outfits that are totally unique (assuming you have some epic stuff to equip and in some cases, even if you don't!).\n\nAs you continue to level up, you just look cooler and cooler. The ships are sick as well and since you can choose 3 separate factions (Klingon, Romulan, Fedreration) then you have a choice of some sweet Romulan ships (which are all epic thanks to their singularity warp drive ftw) or if you want a cool Klingon Bird-of-Prey or a classic (or newer!) Federation ship (also, any race can play any faction). The weapons have become more and more epic over the years just like everything else in STO. 100% Worth a shot, if you've been uncertain about whether or not to go for it, now would be the time. Especially since it's free!!!!!

reviewText:
It is a very amusing game, but the developers need to focus more on overhauling instead of adding new stuff.

The engine could use a major upgrade, I think it is still the same engine as they used in 2010, when the game launched.
(It would be cool to see that impacts actually do damage. That way, escorts would actually make use of their mobility)

Several story arcs could use a major overhaul, the Cardassian arc and the Breen arc for example.
Space flight could also use some tweaks. I would like to be able to turn in all directions like IRL space, and not be stuck to a 65* angle for upwards / downwards.

Ground combat NEEDS a major overhaul! Ground Combat is pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ right now!

Also, it would be good to see more exploration and less wars. I think we've got our share of that now :)

however, the game is very amusing when you play with friends, so ill recommend it!

reviewText:
Star Trek OnlineSo I have played this game for quite a while, but I will try to be non-biased. SO, HERE WE GO.
Pros Solid Leveling System, (although it does go to grinding later in the game)
Lots of Customization (unlike most MMO-RPGs, the character customization is done through the talior shops. This means that Costumes are purely cosmetic)
Game has a great Space Combat System
Character Creation: You can choose from 3 factions, Klingon Empire, Starfleet, and Romulan Republic. Past factions, you can choose from 3 classes, Tactical, Engineer, and Science. There are also a bunch of races, including: Human, Betazoid, Talaxian, Andorian, and so on.
Meh Story
4 Player Co-op
Active DevsCons PvP is Dead
Strange Mini-Map
PvE Queues have long wait times
Meh Graphics
Meh Story
GrindingMeh Meh Story
Men Graphics
Optional GrindingConclusionIt's a good game, a really good game. Not GoTY Material, but still great. Just buy it please!
(Please join Mars Defense Perimeter)

EDIT: as a side note the game does microtransactions, but i completed the main story on my first character only spending $10 (Spent on purely cosmetic items).

reviewText:
First off I started to play it 5 days ago and I am already a level 25 Klingon and have a tier 3 ship so yes it is adictive.

Star Trek On-Line can be a little overwhelming at first stat of playing with all that is going on and I am stil learning and trying to grasp it all.

There is research to do with your officers, setting skill points for yourself and your officers as well as promoting them.

There are joint effort missions like Borg invsions to beat. You have away missions on both ships and planets. You can explore the inside of your ship real time and interact with all department heads in each area plus your bridge crew. All ships are fully customizable from interiors to exterior colors. You get a free ship choice on each Rank level you make.

All in all I am saying a good game and you really can accomplish a lot with the total free play. But I have to admit there are a few aspects that you might want to put a dime or two into it like for the lock box keys and increaseing your inventory size because you can loose some stuff once it is full and you forget to sell what you do not want.

You can play dobble, drink at bars, interact with people on planets and many star systems to explore. And missions are easy to find and get tossed at you often.

All I can say is try it out for free see how you like it and then go from there.

reviewText:
Pretty neat MMORPG.

WHAT I LIKE
No mindless, repetitive grinding required. There are LOTS of missions to go around and they are fine to level you up to the highest levels. Once you reach those levels, there are STILL more missions to go around. Lol.

Ground AND space combat. <3

Lots of customization options for character and starship appearance and equipment.
All the customization options yield a variety of different playstyles, so there are lots of things to try.

Co-op play is actually beneficial, and there are events in missions that only specific classes (tactical, engineering, or science) can do. If you have a buddy who plays a different class, then you can take advantage of more events than you would playing alone.

WHAT I DISLIKE
Paying into the game definitely yields an advantage, especially in PvP. However, for the most part, it SEEMS that free players can still acquire the fancy combat equipment and what not by putting more time and effort into the game. There are aesthetic elements that can be acquired only with Zen (the currency you get by buying with real monies), but they don't really affect the outcome of battles; they're just for looks.

PvP can get really annoying with hardcore players who have MUCH better equipment than newer players, and who will not relent, thereby spoiling the experience for others.

After a while, it can get repetitive. The vast majority of missions involve space combat, ground combat, then space combat, travel to a different system, and have more space combat.

Overall, I like it, but wouldn't pay for it.

reviewText: A young boy and a talented stray dog with an amazing basketball playing ability become instant friends. Rebounding from his father's accidental death, 12-year-old Josh Framm moves with his family to the small town of Fernfield, Washington. The new kid in town, Josh has no friends and is too shy to try out for the school basketball team. Instead he prefers to practice alone on an abandoned court, he befriends a runaway golden retriever named Buddy. Josh is amazed when he realizes that Buddy loves basketball...that is playing basketball...and he is GOOD! Josh eventually makes the school team and Buddy is named the Team Mascot. Josh and Buddy become the stars of halftime. Buddy's half-time talent draws media attention. Unfortunately, when Buddy's mean former owner, Norm Snively, comes along with a scheme to cash in on the pup's celebrity, it looks like they are going to be separated.

Good stuff:

- AWESOME and interesting main storyline, something very very rare in MMORPGS.

- There are no silly quests like kill 10 xyz for no reason" or "bring me 10 xyz  items for no reason"
date: but serious storyline driven quests.\n\n- Game is just awesome
recommended:
even to people who never actually seen any Star Trek movie.

- It is possible to gain xp and money even when offline due then awesome crew missions.

- Very impressive graphics in space.

Bad stuff:

- I completed about 90% of game
hoursPlayed:
and I never did anything together (except of Borg defense missions) with other players. It feels like single player game mostly unless player choose to do pvp.

- Storyline is little-bit too complex to remember and process by normal people. (but its awesome!)

MMORPG with AWESOME and interesting storyline (not because of Star Trek!). Not just for nerds.

reviewText: If you like space ships, have some fun with this game. However, the devs have essentially bolted a microtransaction/grindfest on every aspect of their game now. If you do decide to to put some money into it, buy your ingame currency through the ARC store. It is a pain but if you try and go through steam, PWE doesn't like that and will lock any gear you buy with the currency to your account. Such a thing isn't bad if you're just upgrading your own ships. But if your intent is to sell the gear on the exchange, maybe you want one of those shiny lockbox ships, you're sol.\n\nGive the game a try, just watch out for their greed hammer. I for one, don't recommend it.

reviewText: If you're wondering if you should play this game there's only one word I can think of... Don't. The controls during away missions are poor. Servicable, but poor. reviewText: Alright. Not going to lie...I'm a bit of a geek when it comes to Star Trek.  This MMO continues to surprise me. Namely, I started playing it when it first launched (and it was a subscription based MMO). Cryptic did a good job, but to be honest, they launched it too early, and it felt like it was halfway done.  The Federation side had a good amount of content, but the Klingon faction, did not.  So after playing it for about a year, I took a break from it (a year plus break).  Coming back to it after so long, even after it went F2P and Cryptic was bought by Perfect World Entertainment, I must say, Cryptic has done an excellent job in expanding the universe.  Not only did they launch a third faction, the Romulans, they also fully fleshed out the Klingon faction.  They also updated the trait system, kit system, and R&D system, while continuing to create Featured Episodes.  That, along with a more robust Foundry (a system that let's the community create playable missions to share), I must say, I've gotten hooked on this game once again.

reviewText: Im going to lay out the short and simple of it for anyone curious about this title. It's good! It has an ever growing end game,  regular free content drops,  regular free item giveaways and special events open to ALL players not just subs or spenders,  the game itself is free with /THE/ best free to play model i have EVER seen.  The ever expanding story is good and you feel like you are a captain shaping the fate of your galaxy. The leveling process is quick and painless allowing you to focus on a good endgame featuring queued missions,  a newly revamped crafting system,  duty officer missions (a game within a game where you send your crew out to perform tasks on timed away missions,  they can suceed,  fail,  become injured,  die! Better duty officers provide special bonuses that improve your space or ground game by slotting them)  a newly revamped character trait system with meaningful and very well balanced traits to give to your captain that make very noticible changes in their abilities or give them whole new abilities!\n\nThis game is highly recomended for anyone that enjoys start trek.. You got nothing to lose on this game,  its a no brainer.

reviewText:
(While the review shows ive only played .8 hours of this game through steam i own a hard copy of the game i use to install so its not listed on steam. And i have played since closed beta.)

Overall quality of this game is bad. Ive been with this game since its beta and it was shipped unfinished to meet a contract deadline, they (the devs) admited this. Major problems from the beta are still present in the game now years later. devs barely update the game at all and when they do it normaly breaks it worse for a few months then it goes back to what it was before with like one spelling error fixed in one converation nobody reads anyway. The games ingame store makes the game pay to win, but all that money you are paying them they are not putting towards developing the game.  Feature episodes (their version of a tv show episode) which are kinda like mini events that move forwards the timel ine of the game and cost alot of dev time can most of the time out of a 6 weeks for 6 parts series be completed in 30 minutesabout 5 min for a part some of the parts are purely walls of text to read and complete in less then 2 min.

Actual gameplay of this game is in a word repetative. Go here kill this. Go here collect this. Go here kill this to collect this. Completely missing the point of the story telling that was any of the TV shows, starfleet rarely uses lethal force or force at all to achieve there goals but thats all you do in this game. Once in a blue moon you come across an interesting quest line but most are sub par, literaly narrow hallways with the entrance on one end, 4 groups of enemies to kill and a conversation at the end. Time to max level in this game taeks about 4 to 6 weeks. Ground combat in this game is a joke it lacks anything to make it fun, boreing interiors for all but 6 missions. Space combat is not in much better shape but at least they spent time here usualy interesting looking locations but still repetative combat, enter mission - kill 4 groups - conversation - leave.

Dev comepletely fail at understanding how to make a game. There are enemies in the game that have a 0% chance to miss you and deal 10 times your health and sheilds combined both in ground and space. This is to add challenge" to the game when in reality they skimped out on making the game made it kill you so you would have to eather try again and hope you DPS it to death before it can react or you grind some repetative mission to crap xp to become higher level then the guy to go back through the whole mission again to kill him and continue the sub par story that you dont even remember why your in the same exact looking base killing another dude.

(While the review shows ive only played .8 hours of this game through steam i own a hard copy of the game i use to install so its not listed on steam. And i have played since closed beta.)

Overall quality of this game is bad. Ive been with this game since its beta and it was shipped unfinished to meet a contract deadline, they (the devs) admited this. Major problems from the beta are still present in the game now years later. devs barely update the game at all and when they do it normaly breaks it worse for a few months then it goes back to what it was before with like one spelling error fixed in one converation nobody reads anyway. The games ingame store makes the game pay to win, but all that money you are paying them they are not putting towards developing the game.  Feature episodes (their version of a tv show episode) which are kinda like mini events that move forwards the timel ine of the game and cost alot of dev time can most of the time out of a 6 weeks for 6 parts series be completed in 30 minutesabout 5 min for a part some of the parts are purely walls of text to read and complete in less then 2 min.

Actual gameplay of this game is in a word repetative. Go here kill this. Go here collect this. Go here kill this to collect this. Completely missing the point of the story telling that was any of the TV shows, starfleet rarely uses lethal force or force at all to achieve there goals but thats all you do in this game. Once in a blue moon you come across an interesting quest line but most are sub par, literaly narrow hallways with the entrance on one end, 4 groups of enemies to kill and a conversation at the end. Time to max level in this game taeks about 4 to 6 weeks. Ground combat in this game is a joke it lacks anything to make it fun, boreing interiors for all but 6 missions. Space combat is not in much better shape but at least they spent time here usualy interesting looking locations but still repetative combat, enter mission - kill 4 groups - conversation - leave.

reviewText:
I have played this game since before its official release, and honestly if it wasn't for the fact it is the ONLY star trek game I would have left a long time ago.

Even before the Delta Rising season, the grind was pretty intense just to get to decent equipment or event items.   After Delta Rising, there was a simultaneous heavy double-nerf where raids and queues were increased in difficulty by large measures, while simultaneously slashing queue rewards.

The grind, especially after level 50 just to get decent equipment is huge and extreme and the rewards underwhelming.  Pair this with the fact Cryptic and PWE aren't able to clearly communicate even basic information to the user makes for a very frustrating experience for new users or users that expect basic competence from a development entity.

The game is slowly dying, Delta Rising itself has seen a pretty big downturn in users, and most of the late game mission queues are never populated as they are too difficult to complete for the rewards.

If you jump in, don't spend a dime on the game.  You are probably better off finding a new MMO with a more stable technology base.

The fact I had to write a non-recommend for this game makes me sad.  It had potential, but all that potential was suffocated by terrible direction and management.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The continuing adventures in Gene Roddenberry's classic sci-fi series, taking place in the original timeline, not the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ J.J. Abrams one. Starfleet has gone back to war with the Klingons (because why not) and you get to pick your side (you can also play as a Romulan, but they have to pick a side 2-3 hours in anyway).

Voyage on a starship you get to name, as an Ensign, and command, because everyone else dies. Explore strange new worlds, that are neither strange or new, just cookie cutter. Seek out new life and new civilizations, except that sounds boring, we'll just give you some super easy ground and tedious (and still easy) space combat.

Go boldly where everyone else has gone before, yet you'll still be alone, as there's no reason to party up. Ever.

reviewText: I got this game a long time ago when it first came out. I was and am a long time ST fan so I was very excited. After getting the game I was surprised how bad it was. Space combat was super tedious and slow, quests were all the same and everything was confined to small areas. How am I supposed to boldly go where no man has gone before when I'm confined to a small area like its an instance? If you've ever played the DnD MMO then you will know what I mean. It was the first MMO that I didn't play out the free month. They would have had to change pretty much the entire game for it to be good. By all means get the game and play it, but do so before you shell out a dime of your money.

reviewText: Although the game is enjoyable, one first has to surpass a host of technical challenges and issues - most of which plague users after the game is installed. These include gameclient.exe errors, random crashes to desktop (without a report feature), crashes to desktop (which do trigger the report feature), disconnects, and memory leaks.\n\nIn the 36 hours preceding this review, my client crashed out 23 times on an Asus 673JH-A1 with up-to-date drivers, making STO one of the buggiest games I've ever encountered. (This also takes the prize from Trion's Defiance
date: which gained quick post-launch notoriety for its bugs, glitches, and other game-breaking features.)\n\nCompany technical support, or lack thereof, complicates the picture. Cryptic is known by this point as Chronic" due to their persistent inability to launch a major patch without breaking at least one major feature - leading to at least 2-5 subsequent patches to fix whatever was originally broken. Technical support is also nonexistent
recommended: meaning you're on your own for troubleshooting and support.\n\nIn short
hoursPlayed: definitely would not recommend this game.\n\nUpdate: After not playing the game for about 4 months
voteText: I reinstalled it on a whim and was promptly met by 3 crashes in an hour. At this point I'm giving up. No game is worth this level of aggravation."

reviewText:
I have always loved Star Trek; and as such, that will tend to make my review biased. However, I think it is fair to say that I will lay down what I feel about this game in a rather fair form. For the longest time, there have not been many great attempts at recreating the Star Trek universe in a game. Some of the best Star Trek games I would argue; go back to the late 1990's and early 2000's; where Star Trek Armada, Klingon Academy, Star Trek Voyager: Elite Force and Bridge Commander were some of the best titles. Later down the road; such as the mid to late 2000's, you had some titles but none were particularly worth playing.

Star Trek Online comes around, and yes: The launch was dissapointing for many who expected it to be a in-depth Bridge Commander style game; not to mention other details seem to have went missing from the game. This is partially due to the collapse of Perpetual Entertainment and the acquisition and development over to Cryptic. The game originally was a monthly fee based game; but eventually it turned Free to Play. I played it for a while years ago but have since been convinced to pick it up and see how it is.

I have to say, I am quite impressed with it. The game overall makes you feel like you are in charge of a ship and you even go under the sensation of living in the shoes of a captain; the amount of things to do and the quality of the mission narratives makes the game rather interesting and not so much a typical boring MMO.

Pros:
1. Free to Play system is fair. (There is purchase content, but it doesn't upset balance.)
2. Customization galore. (Ships, uniforms, officers, loadouts, etc. Lots of cosmetic choices.)
3. Solo friendly environment. (You don't need to be with others to succeed. You can team up; but the game doesn't require it.)
4. Large Officer roster. (Bridge officers that can operate your ship's systems. Assign teams to go away on missions outside your ship.)
5. Space combat mechanics. (Want to focus shield energy on a given side? Want to increase power to weapons? You are in control.)
6. Not a grindfest game. (Want to hit the level cap? This game doesn't make you spend countless hours of your life to get to that point.)
7. Foundry missions. (User generated missions that have their own plot and objectives. They can vary in quality; but it is player freedom.)
8. Star Trek MMO. (Star Trek fans like this. This is totally not obvious, right?)
9. Mission types. (Not every mission involves combat or fighting, some are simple scan or repair missions.)
10. Mission narrative. (Some missions make you think of yourself fulfilling the role in a Star Trek episode.)

Cons:
1. Player community. (It is a free to play game, so this is sort of expected. Players get too political sometimes and often immature. Sometimes it is difficult to make inquiries in chat, etc. Not everyone likes this kind of environment.)
2. Enemy bosses. (This is more of a annoying trope than a real problem. Enemy bosses such as the villain" type always seem to escape you.)
3. Linear missions. (There are plenty of them that offer different solutions to a problem; but many missions don't have multiple outcomes.)
4. Away team issues. (The away teams that you bring into combat will never try to revive you unless they are not fighting. Sometimes Away team members don't maintain unit coherency.)
5. Some visuals. (Some planet textures on even the highest settings still look blocky and ugly.)
6. Customer service. (The customer service is known to be on the poor side. Lack of sincerity and cooperation when issues arise in cases.)

Overall
date: this MMO is definitely worth playing; even if you are not into Star Trek; the game itself is quite entertaining and full of things to do. There is a lot of purchase content; but it isn't required to actually succeed in playing and enjoying the game."

reviewText: Star Trek Online, the only game in the league of Star Trek games that are actually fairly enjoyable for more than 10 hours.  This is the reason the game is still going, in all honesty.  Once it adopted the F2P model(largely pay-to-win, but not REQUIRED) it slowly went downhill.\n\nWithout going into too many specifics, the game is on a downhill slope that will end this game's life prematurely.  As anyone knows, MMOs thrive on the grind" and STO is no different.  The problem is that there is no REASON for the grind in STO anymore.  There is no such thing as an endgame.  You will find yourself making more characters to do different things on and only finding there is no endgame for any of them
date: only an endless grind for currency which is no longer useful once you've met the current "endgame".\n\nThe game has also completely gotten rid of all exploration (a staple of Star Trek).  I love blowing things up
recommended: and that's the main reason I play but many hate that the game has also become a DPS race.  This wouldn't be an issue if all roles were DPS but they are not.  There is Science
hoursPlayed: Engineering
voteText: and Tactical.  80% of players seem to be Tactical because of the emphasis on DPS at every turn.  Science and Engineering really only exist to break up monotony of tactical captain play.  Even so
helpfulPercent: both of these classes still try to obtain high DPS(always falling short of what Tac is capable of).\n\nFaction-wise
votesHelpful: there is the Federation
votesTotal: Romulans
votesFunny: and Klingon Empire to chose from.  Romulans and Klingons are grossly ignored in all aspects(even so
commentsCount: Romulan is my favorite and I even deleted my Fed character to make another).  Romulans may chose to be sided with Klinks or the Federation and enjoy a few benefits from their choice(even using there ships that are Tier 4 or lower).\n\nAnother issue is the constant nerfing of your equipment/builds at every turn.   Devs promised Tier 5 was the max (endgame ships
column16: as you will) so they were always the goal to hit.  Get your Tier 5 ship of choice then outfit it till it can reach no higher DPS
column17: at that point you work on piloting and such.  A few months ago Tier 6 were announced
column18: but you can pay to upgrade your T5 ships to T5-U(almost on par with T6) for some cash(real cash).\n\nThese are just some glaring and annoying issues but the game is fun for casual play(an hour a day or so).  If you are a hardcore gamer or serious enough to want to be the best at anything you play
column19: you will come away from the game with hundreds of hours and no satisfaction.  You will also see money disappear from your wallet somehow.\n\nTL:DR:  Fun for awhile
column20: terrible if you want an endgame that is enjoyable.  Avoid if you always want to excel in a game or life."

reviewText: the learning curve is way steep on this game, it is also very confusing at the start. it isn't always clear where you ought to be going and getting the hang off how to get anywhere over longer distances. neither does the game allow you to reset the character, so if anything goes wrong in the tutorial (which is very likely) you have to start ALL OVER again.  the character development is also very advanced (which is an advantage if you have some resetting control over it, this game does not allow any changes, or even respawning after creation). i love star trek, but i hate this game.

reviewText:
Started playing recently, really few hours in game.

TL;DR It could be a good game but P2WE strikes again: pay2win paywall.
I would not mind if it would come with pay 2 skip features, and cosmetic cash shop, but instead the game is just owned now and managed by sheeetheads moneygrabber.

The game while levelling is actually fun, you geta a ship and a crew to command very early in game (VERY), and that is awesome.

But seems like the game became a power creep threadmil with a hefty pay2win paywall with the recent additions (Delta Rising, T6 ships) ...sooo well that looks Ignominiously bad, but i still have to level my toons before going there.

What is very bad is actually that even if you buy a sub, why should i still have to pay for something i do need to play as premium feature? It should come then as a complete game, instead you still need to buy with real money things like ship slots, bridge officer slots, lock box keys... why??? If i pay a sub why do i have to pay more? :[

reviewText: This game used to be fun. This game had just enough challenge to keep you interested. Now, the game has become unplayable. I'm not sure who wrote the code for this game, but ever since October 30th of 2014 the game continues to crash just after the delta rising splashscreen. Before this, grinding used to be interesting with decent rewards for your efforts. Now, it feels like you're working, yes WORKING, to not fall behind. A game should be for fun. It is suppose to be entertaining. This game has been dragged down from its former days of fundom into a true 2nd job. The only thing this software seems to want to achieve is to get the most amount of money from the player as it possibly can. I've tried to enjoy this title. I've put well over 2k hours into this thing. But the recent technical issues and inability to actually play has opened my eyes to how truly little the company cares for the players.

reviewText:
This game has become a bugfest. There are bugs almost everywhere in the game. The developers don't care about fixing them. They turn a blind eye to feedback from the playerbase. On the forums topics are being locked that provide negative feedback about the game. They only focuss on filling their own wallet's. They keep adding broken content and the amount of bugs keeps getting bigger. They fix 1 bug? 10 new bugs appear to replace the one they fixed. Their hardware is crap. Everyone gets disconnected from the game every few hours due to server not responding". Yet the developers keep saying everything is working as intended and that the problem always lies on the side of the customers.

The 5 year anniversary is the latest example of Cryptic's incompetence. The first 48 hours after the 5 year anniversary launch the game was unplayable because of the high amount of players logging into the game at the same time. What was the developer team's response? They told us to wait 2-3 days until everyone has finished patching their clients. Yet again this new content is filled with bugs and some of it isn't even playable because missions can't be completed.

I have never
date: ever seen an MMO go downhill as badly as Star Trek Online. MMO's are supposed to be stable due to the high amount of players playing the game. But with Cryptic? With them: "everything is working as intended". I'm a big fan of Star Trek
recommended: and this game is the closest thing a Star Trek fan can have to an MMO representing the Star Trek universe. But it all gets ruined by a company that is only interested in filling their own pockets. I have endured this mess long enough. But enough is enough.\n\nIf you are curious about the game but not familiar with the world of Star Trek
hoursPlayed: It's not worth it. If you want to see what the world of Star Trek is like
voteText: don't go see it through this game."

reviewText:
Was looking forward to a good all round blast, but the game is not what it seems.
Lots of bugs, and loads of stuff that is not explained to you.
The game is very deep, for insatnce at lvl 10 you get a new ship, at lvl 11, 21 crew who can assign duties to, but that is not explained to you very well, TBH a damn nightmare.
Made a fed character at lvl 10 I was told to go, and do PvP training, but I did not want to do that, but that is all you can do.
This to me just spoilt the story I was following.

Go on to local chat in zone ask anything, and you will get no replies, as i Did.
It is in all essence P2W.
The greed machine will give you loads of nice ships, if you want to throw your hard earned cash around.
After all PWE,Cryptic, and WOTC, made a complete mess of Neverwinter.= with the lvl 6 mod.
Calling all areas at lvl 60 now 70, but too damn lazy to make any new content for lvl 70.
Plus they sacked all there staff who made mod 5.
Dungeons are now a mess.
I had posts closed, because I had a go at the devs, and the company, almost got banned.
They will not have anything said aginst the devs, stuff like that is closed, or deleted by them.

That to me I find chieldish, as there are, so many MMO's out there who just listen, or take it on the chin, but not PWE, or Cryptic.
They will tell you that they make the decisions, not YOU, no matter how you moan.
Look on there forums hard enough, and you will see it, got to admit I was shocked not nice at all, and no need for it.

Am I still playing???, Yes, sad really, but I will not give them a penny, as I know when I hit lvl40 it will be impossible, and I'll get one shot all the time, then I'll just go find something else to have fun on.
To me games should be fun, but not with anything PWE, or Cryptic labelled they take the fun out of it.
GL, Take Care, HF :).

reviewText: Probably the best MMORPG I've played so far.  Still, it suffers from what other MMO's suffer from:  Grinding, people, quadratic leveling, and lost time.  I have heard people say it has one of the best Free-to-play mechanics out of many MMORPG's in that nothing is really locked behind a pay wall.  You just need to grind until your crotch is shiny and radiates tremendous amounts of heat.  While I can't recommend this to anyone who wants to have a life, I can say it's a pretty dang good MMORPG.  Also, I never encountered any Russians or Brazilians, so there's that.

reviewText:
Star Trek Online is a very interesting game, to say the least, but has loads of issues. First of all there is immersion-breaking pop in with characters, entities, special effects, and entire scenes. What I'm talking about here is when the screen transitions from one scene into another it doesn't allow all of the entities to load before coming in from black. So you're frequently left watching strange pop-in with stuff.

There are also numerous control-specific things that just feel... off... like clicking over and over to attack, instead of being able to just hold down the button, to give one example.

It is a great looking game, and worth the price of admision (it is free after all) but I wouldn't really recommend it as something worth spending any significant amount of time playing.

reviewText: this used to be a fantastic...amazing..perfect game...i loved the aspect of it..played it since it went free to play....ship combat was amazing....great style fitting most space sims of its time...ground combat needed work but was a fun expeirance...the game was overall a fantastic peace of work....it wasnt without its bugs and glitches...all mmo's have them...sometimes things get released to early.....to name a few problems from the paste..they released a fantastic escort carrier for the federation......annnnnnnd..it couldnt warp out of any system without crashing the game......and then the borg had a super weapon we called invisible death...(they were invisible torpdoes that you cant avoid and shoot down and one shot you..fantastic) but it was still fun..they were fixed..and the game was great..\n\nthat being said...i can no longer recomend this game..its gone completely wallet happy...paste level 40 if you do not buy a ship for 40 to 60 dollars...you get left behind...you can refine dil in the game to do this..but the cap means you will be at it for months on end..you can improve your weapons!!!.....to higher tiers and more rarity with fantastic improvements.....for dil...which you need to get the ship....you also need....well you need it for everything...the game has quite litterly..and plainly...gone wallet to play....as in paste 40..its pay to play..i can no longer recomend star trek online to anyone.......and this is heart breaking to me...because i have been a star trek fanatic since i was 12.....and i spent so much time..and money on this game..and it shatters my heart seeing its become a buggy game....a glitchy game......based around money.....please...do not waste your time...

reviewText:
Here is the pro to the game:

- Leonard Nimoy narrates and is the voice in the datalog

That is all.

If you know nothing about Star Trek and are looking for a space RPG combat game, this still is a poor choice but not the worst.  However, for a game based on a franchise that were resolved around conflict resolution, problem solving and ingenuity, this game took out all three and decided to make a space combat game.  The characters are unimaginative and the missions consist of Space Ship combat - ground combat - Space Ship Combat, lather-rinse-repeat.  It's not about exploration, it's about being the Federation's enforcement.  Not worth it.
voteText: 14 of 27 people (52%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
What I liked about STO (Star Trek Online) is impossible to say. After all, I never got that far because tech support was unable to answer a simple query concerning which domains to whitelist (other than perfectworld.com) in order to get it running on a secure system. Let's start from the beginning:
.
My system is specially set up so that JavaScript, etc.,  runs correctly on my system only when served from a whitelisted domain. From any other domain it gets shut down - which is how I know that STO is served, in part, from unspecified domains other than perfectworld.com and these other domains are, consequently, not whitelisted by my security.
.
What takes the cake is that, when I asked tech support for the domain names which needed to be whitelisted for the game to work, they responded by stating that the game works for “millions” of other people - which dodged the question by employing an argument by irrelevance; a form of sophistry known as a fallacy. I have to wonder if these guys even bothered to read the support ticket I lodged (given their total failure to comprehend the problem I raised) and why they couldn't simply address my question (as opposed to addressing some purely imaginary complaint).
.
Now, when support techs start engaging in sophistry, it can mean that they are more interested in griefing the customers than doing their job. Moreover, this reflects very poorly on management, for obvious reasons; principally because it demonstrates the attitude that they can do no wrong and it is always someone-else's fault which, ultimately, gives rise to a fundamental disrespect for the customer base.
.
The bottom line is that I recommend strongly against STO and, moreover, I will not be reviewing this game again until I see some sort of evidence that key management changes have been made which facilitate policy implementation designed to ensure that customers are not systematically marginalised for the apparent crime of asking for some technical support.

reviewText:
The game's sound and visiuals are very solid, actually, and the space combat was reminiscent of the enjoyable Starfleet Command games (no longer in circulation, as far as I know). The problems come from:

1) Redundancy. A lot of missions are go to a place and seek out multiple groups of enemies; return when you've killed x number of them

2) Ground combat. It's tedious. Additionally, the character movements are very jumpy on ground missions

Anyway, it was fun for a while, but didn't have anything to hold interest. Just more and more of the same grind, essentially.

reviewText:
So right off the bat, I'm going to make the claim that if you're a Star Trek fan, you'll find something to love about this game.

Whether it's the episodic campaign that draws heavily upon the series and films. Or the vast overworld that allows you to beam down to many of the iconic locations you've come to know and love, such as Deep Space Nine, Starfleet Academy, Earth Stardock, Risa, and, taken directly from the most beloved film of the series, Paradise City from ST V. (Kidding.) Or just being able to run around your own ship or shuttle, most of which are inspired by, or are of the same class as, the ones from the show/films, and pilot it around the galaxy. There's something in this game for everyone.

Since most people here have already covered the big parts of the game, I'll point my own personal list of Pros and Cons:

PROS:

- Fantastic Campaign: The devs for STO are big time Trek fans, and you'll definitely discover this once you start making your way through the campaign of your choice: Starfleet, Romulan, or Klingon. Each episode is formatted like an episode of the show, most of which are heavily inspired by plotlines from the show and films. Some of the episodes even continue the stories of some ST characters. Some devolve into shoot-'em-ups, but most -- especially the recent ones -- are 100% Trek, on par with the show. There are also player-created missions available to play through by way of the Foundry, which is awesome and something I wish more MMOs would incorporate.

- Frequent Updates: Cryptic update the game with major episodic content a few times a year, most of which have featured actors reprising their roles from the series, such as Michael Dorn (Worf), Tim Russ (Tuvok), and Denise Crosby (Tasha Yar). Leonard Nimoy also narrates many key parts of the game in-character as Spock. Each new episode has added new story content, dailies, and general updates -- and all of them have been free. We've had one full-fledged expansion, Legacy of Romulus, and another one on the way in October called Delta Rising.

- The Star Trek Experience: A lot went into making the game feel like a genuine Trek experience. The general atmosphere, the scale of the overworld, the missions, the visuals, locations, and characters. You take command of your own ship, and you can pretty much roll up any character you can imagine: from the stock races, such as Human, Vulcan, Romulan, Klingon, Betazoid, Trill, Orion, etc., to a custom alien race that you can define. There are also a lot of RP opportunites: Dabo(!), asteroid mining, ship interiors, and seasonal events. Just a lot of great stuff.

- F2P Model: If I had to make a list of the most ethical F2P MMOs on the market... it would be a short list, but STO would be near the top. All of the story, PvE, and PvP content is free, as are all the updates. Most of the things Cryptic are making money off of are cosmetic items (uniforms, ship interiors/exteriors), ships (but the free ships are just as competitive), and services like inventory space, character slots, bank space, etc. The two things that I would count against it are the lockboxes, which can be easily ignored, and the two races locked behind a paywall, though with nearly infinite races available to you, it doesn't make much of a difference in my opinion. With a model like this, I've been happy to support it since I started playing.

KHANS:

- Sector Space: Initially, it's no big deal, but after some time you start to realize how unintuitive Sector Space can be, sectioned off the way it is. Can you land here, orbit, or do nothing? Why are there invisible walls in space? There's an event here, but is anyone participating? What does the event even entail? Cryptic have stated in the past that they want to give Sector Space an overhaul, which would be awesome, but we still have it for now.

- Instance Stagnation: There are a lot of PvE and PvP instances to queue up for. People play a select few, but most have stagnated -- not from lack of players, just lack of interest. I'd much rather them not be there if no one's going to play them, so that Cryptic would be able to put more focus on the ones people still enjoy.

- Community: Do yourself a favor and find a good fleet that you can get along with, because the community in STO, at least the vocal part, might just drive you insane. This is nothing new to online games, but it seems abnormal in a Trek game. Part of the reason might be how fragmented chat is in STO, which makes moderation rather difficult. Making chat universal across individual sectors would make things better, I think, but for now reading ESD chat might just make you go blind.

I think that about covers it! Like I said, if you're a Star Trek fan, you owe it to yourself to give this a try, especially now that we're on the verge of a new expansion.

Live long and prosper!

reviewText:
Star Trek Online (STO) is a solid MMORPG with tons of customization option for those who are willing to work for it.  It is not, however, a good Star Trek game.

For me, the main draw of Star Trek isn't so much the science fiction, which let's face it, is on the silly side.  It is the characters, the dynamics between the crew that makes it interesting.  In-game, however, crew members are treated as little more than equipment, so that personal connection is gone.  You gain the ability to customize your officers however you want, true, but you lose what makes them characters.

Another problem of the game is the randomly generated sidequests.  Sure, it's fun to pretend that you are the star of your own Star Trek show, routinely investigating strange species, artifacts, and negative space wedgies, but the mad-lib style of quest generation means that after a while, all these quests seem to blur together.  So aside from the story quests - which are well done, by the way - none of the other content is memorable.

The saving grace for these sidequests is the Foundry, which allows users to create their own quests and stories.  Sturgeon's Law is in full effect here; 90% of the custom content is lackluster, but the other 10% makes it worthwhile.

While the game has problems that prevent it from being truly great, I would still recommend it for ♥♥♥♥♥♥mers.  The universe feels big, the ship-to-ship combat is frantic but tactical (although sometimes you fight with the UI more than the enemy), and the amount of reference to the Star Trek shows can make Star Trek enthusiasts giddy.  If these sound exciting, that this is the game for you.

reviewText:
I would recommend this game to those who enjoy space battle games, MMOs, or specifically Star Trek! The game contains a lot of elements I enjoy, lacks in a few areas, but mostly is a great game! I tend to take my time, with my own method of how I play the game, making logs for every mission I do. Like an actual Starfleet Officer would do, as far as I know. The whole Star Trek franchise is my 3rd favorite (set of) show(s). The games story throws me off, the Federation allied or has a peace treaty with both the Klingons and the Romulans, I don't know why they are considered enemies. Especially when the 3 sides that you can be on, don't really fight one another. I haven't gotten much into the campaign yet to really know and understand the story, but as far as I can tell, I just enjoy being able to be a Starfleet Officer and having my own ship, and of course making my own logs.

Issues I have with this game:
1. You can't customize your ship fully. You can, somewhat, but I wish there was a more detailed way to modify your ship.
2. You can't change your first officers information. This kind of bugged me, I wish I could change my first officers details just as I can change my first officers appearance, but the game doesn't allow it.
3. You can't train your officers in like a holodeck program, which I wish you could build your own training programs and have access to a holodeck program. That way you can train your officers and even earn experience for yourself, maybe?
4. You have to buy a lot of things with no free way really to earn a few Zen coins every now and then.

Other than the issues I have with the game, the game is really fun and enjoyable! Even for a MMO. Although having it a single player game would have been cooler, that way they probably would of payed attention to how you build your ship, or design your character, and all of that rather than focusing on how the PVP system will work. Like with most MMO's, you can't really summarize the story without going through most of the game. So I can't summarize the story for this game.

reviewText:
Short review: This game is absolutely worth your time.  The crafting system is simplistic, the build mechanics complex enough to provide lots of diversity, and the ship battles are ultimately quite fun and engaging in ways that few other MMOs can manage.  The game's bugs and shortfalls (ground combat in particular) are more than compensated by the range of content and useful ways to spend your time, and this MMO is among a very select few MMOs which has an in-game system designed to reward you even when you're not playing.  Since it's all free, it's worth your time to try it out.

If that's all you needed to see, then you can stop reading here.

However, I want to spend the bulk of this review explaining the negative" reviews you see
date:
because they all stem from the same common attitude that an increasing number of gamers tend to suffer from: an unwillingness to put forth the effort to EARN things.

Something you may notice about this game is that many of the top negative reviewers have two things in common:
1) They're mostly bashing the studio (not the actual game) for perceived slights and its "pay to win model".
2) Despite their supposed hatred of the game
recommended: they've sunk hundreds if not thousands of hours into it anyways.\n\nIt's not as hard to understand how this is possible
hoursPlayed: if you spend a bit of time playing the game for yourself.  STO is
voteText: simply put
helpfulPercent: a lot of fun to play
votesHelpful: and this is something many of these negative reviews either ignore or begrudgingly admit somewhere in the footnotes of their massive rants against the game's payment structure.\n\nThis is
votesTotal: of course
votesFunny: mostly misplaced rage from people who either don't understand the currency system or lack any semblance of patience (the "gimme" crowd that is all too common to MMOs).\n\nThe payment system is relatively simplistic: Everything that can be bought for real money uses the "zen" currency (at a rate of $1 per 100 zen).  Some ships and a multitude of other ship devices and items cost dilithium
commentsCount: which is obtained in-game for free at a relatively slow pace.  This game also features a trade system whereby you can trade zen for dilithium and vice versa
column16: meaning that anything you can buy for real money could potentially be bought entirely for free
column17: with enough time and patience.\n\nIt takes a LOT of dilithium to do this
column18: naturally (usually 150 dil for 1 zen)
column19: so you will be doing some grinding for it.  However
column20: the grinding is not that bad by comparison to typical MMO grinding as dilithium can be obtained several ways (dilithium farming can be done through a variety of daily quests across the entire universe
column21: as well as through duty officer missions and PvE queues).  The only real limiting factor is the fact that you can only produce 8k "refined" dilithium per day
column22: per character (and dilithium must be refined in order to exchange it for zen)
column23: which generally doesn't prove to be much of a problem for me.\n\nIf I were to pick at anything
column24: it would be that the Zen-based costs of ships do feel prohibitively high (ranging from 500 to 3k zen
column26: but this is primarily a consequence of the fact that they are account-wide ship unlocks (meaning any character of yours in that same faction gets access to them)
column27: as well as the fact that dilithium can be used to supplement part or all of these costs with enough time and patience.  The people who are whining about Cryptic's "pay to win" model are mostly complaining because these items cannot be obtained for free very easily if you lack the time or patience to put in the work for them.  In my own experience with many MMOs
column28: this one is hardly as "pay-to-win" as they want it to sound.  Cryptic gives you a chance at a unique top-tier ship via the lockbox system if you're willing to spend your dilithium on keys for the lockboxes instead.  And on top of that
column29: they even throw events which allow you to unlock a top-tier ship entirely for free (such as during Q's Winter Wonderland) with enough time put in.\n\nSo suffice it to say you can do far
column30: far worse than STO if you want to talk "pay to win".  This game by no means fits that bill
column31: not when you can buy anything in the real money store for free with enough hard work.  It's attitudes like those of the "popular" negative votes against this game which help fuel the stereotype of "gamer entitlement" that many often refer to.  Truthfully
column33: and you ought not to let these people fool you into thinking otherwise."

reviewText: STO is a marvelous continuation of the Star Trek television series, and it's  free. For this reason I would have reccomended it even before I'd sunk 2k+ hours into it. If you don't like MMOs, turn off chat and nametags and bam, you have the best Star Trek single-player game produced.

reviewText: For years my favorite Star Trek game was Birth of the Federation, but this is the first title to unseat that position. It's also my first MMORPG, a category that I was never interested until I decided to install STO. Boy, am I glad I decided to give this one a try. The fact that it's free to play gets rid of a major obstacle. If you enjoy the rich world created by Gene Roddenberry and built upon by hundreds of other writers and artists, you may love this game. The developers of this game clearly studied the various Trek series and have infused the game with that knowledge. Playing through various missions sometimes feels like getting to watch a new episode of Trek, only this time it's starring yourself!

reviewText: Star Trek Online is a very well designed program with seemingly endless features in-game.  Although I would change sector space to a spherical version, mirroring the real milky way, I have found moving about space in an assault cruiser is more than simple.  Combat and communicating should be improved, as well as, PVE scenarios.  Overall, however, the game is GREAT!!!

reviewText: Been playin STO for a long long while Bought it when it first came out" and I have to say that out of all the F2P models I have seen this one is one of the best. You can get whatever you want in the cash shop without spending a dime
date: you do this by mining and trading on the Dilithium market which is basically a form of currency that you can exchange for Cash Shop Zen. HOWEVER
recommended: be prepared to put in the time if you choose to go that route.\n\nBiggest problem I have seen with this game is the players who actually play it. Those that dont put money into the game are constantly ♥♥♥♥♥ing about the "advantage" other players have over them and Earth Spaceport has become a literal soapbox for these people to voice their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Despite the fact that if these people simply just put some time into the game they could have everything a paid player has access too as well. Putting money into the game is simply a time saving convinence
hoursPlayed: not a game breaking flaw. As many of these people would lead you to believe.\n\nBesides
voteText: there is a mission where you take a current generation Ship
helpfulPercent: slingshot around the sun
votesHelpful: go back in time to TOS. And get drink recipes from Scotty... That alone should make you want to play. Graphics I have noticed are getting a bit dated and certain aspects of space combat will take you a moment to learn. But
votesTotal:
other than that the game is enjoyable and fun.

10/10 Would go back in time to get alcohol recipes from Scotty again.

"

reviewText: Now there are a multitude of problems that rear its head with Star Trek Online: Glitches Galore, Not much in game benefits for being part of a fleet, Starfleet feels really obsolete when you unlock the ability to become part of the KDF and Romulan Empire and the pretty much very similar story missions even if you are part of a different faction. This game screams Generic MMO" and has done for its 5 year life cycle. There is one thing though that no other Star Trek licensed or really any Licensed Sci-Fi games have ever done
date: Made you feel like the Captain of your very own ship and your very own crew that you build yourself through hours of work. For so long i have craved a game that could make me feel like i was part of such a universe like Star Trek's and that i could create my own story and be that Starfleet/KDF/Romulan Captain. If i am quite honest if you are someone looking for an MMO and do not have the faintest idea of Star Trek's lore or have no interest in Sci-Fi then turn away as this will be frustrating and excruciating to the core. But for those who want "To boldly go where no man has gone before" and are self declared members of Starfleet then this game will provide hours upon hours of entertainment
recommended: even with the games numerous issues. I should know
hoursPlayed: I have played the blasted game for almost 195 Hours..."
voteText: February 19, 2015
helpfulPercent: true
votesTotal: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The game is good in single player, but absolutely horrible as MMO.  Then the lastest expansion came out increasing level grind from a few days to months or years forcing you to repeat the same 3 minute content thousands of times. Every ship you want to fly will cost  you 30 dollars or spending all day every day collecting pink rocks like full time work to buy them for free. They give one faction that no one plays insane damage (romulans) and anything other factions get is nerfed to nothingness. They increased monster health 10x while maybe increasing damage 50% so you can spend half an hour shooting at same guy. They turned a casual exploration based game into a full time job. The only people defending this are those who have unlimited time or funding and want to feel superior.

reviewText:
This is the only game I own a life sub to.

'nuff said.

Still...

Pros:
- evolving gameworld.
- devs which mostly listen to the community.
- community is no worse than any other.

Cons:
- changing gameworld.
- It is my humble belief that LOCKBOXES MUST BE REMOVED IN EVERY GAME EVER, including this one.
- Star Trek must mean different things to different generations, because there are way too many bigots in zone chat for my liking (see above:  'community is no worse than any other')

I'm just trying to be honest. I love this game, but I'm not playing it at the moment, because I hate the changes. But I'll check it out again in a few months, and probably fall in love all over again. That's what keeps happening, and that's why I recommend it.

reviewText: This game is very very fun even if you don't have any idea what Star Trek is. I started when one of my friends was playing and was like oh that game looks like fun" and i really wasn't that into Star Trek. I now love Star Trek and this game. but enough about that
date:
you probably want to know about the game not my personal experience.

Pros:
+Fun gameplay
+Many different races to play as
+Three factions: KDF
hoursPlayed:
and Romulan
+Good story
+F2P
+Can create fleets with other people
+Can ram enemies
+Partial voice acting
+Pretty good audio
+You command your own starship
+You have Duty Officers that you can put on assignment to do stuff
+Crafting
+There are tribbles

Cons:
-There are tribbles
-Gameplay can get a little repetative
-Hard to make EC (the currency) if you don't know what you're doing
-Servers are a little buggy/slow
-Ground combat is a little buggy if you use shooter mode
-Can be pay 2 win if you don't know what you're doing
-A skill is required to ram enemies
-You might find yourself becoming a Trekkie
-Leonard Nimoy is dead. RIP :(
"

reviewText: This game was fun for a time.  Then, I tried to get my second ship.  I got a free token for another ship and went to turn it in and both the OK and CANCEL buttons did the same thing...nothing.  My token was gone and no new ship.  So, I played for a few days and built up enough Dilithium to purchase the Cruiser ship (15000).  I went to purchase the ship, my Dilithium disappeared and in the chat window it said I received the Cruiser, but sadly no ship.\n\nGranted, I was using a free account, but if free accounts are not allowed a second ship, why does my Ship Slots show 5 available and both my token and Dilithium were depeleted?  What's worse is the bug reporting system wouldn't let me notify the developers of this issue.  Shotty programming guys.  If you would have kept me happy on the free account, I would have became a paying member, but I don't think I want to waste anymore time or ANY money on this product.

reviewText:
I have a Mac Pro (2013 model) - top of the line, but the Wine wrapper has enough issues that it doesn't do much but crash.  Lowering settings, replacing drivers, uninstalling/reinstalling - this is not a good sign for the game's future.

If you're going to support a game on certain platforms, make sure it works on said platforms.

Edit: I've spent the better part of two days trying to troubleshoot the issue.  This is common to have issues with Macs.  The Wine Wrapper doesn't commit a true scan on anything on your system when launching (for example, whethere I have an on-board graphics card or a behemoth, it doesn't care).  Again, for PC users - you might have a blast, especially for a free-to-play model, but I stand by what I said.

reviewText: STO is 99% grinding and only 1% gameplay. if you want to loose your real life and friends and never see the sun again and spend thousands of dollar for crap, then go ahead and play sto. the game is full with never fixed bugs, boring cutscenes you cant escape, more boring pvp and pve missions, bad comic-like graphics, every 20 minutes you get a game crash, the network code is very slow and you will get a ton of lag and rubberbanding all the time, the login and loading of the game takes ages the first 5 minutes you cant do anything and i have a fast ssd, huge amount of fast ram and fast connection so its not the fault of my system, the game clipping is horrible everything is warping around, the episode mission storys make no sense at all, the support doesnt even exist they will rather harras you instead of help you, everywhere they have added timegates i still wonder why they havent added timegates even for the beamout process. the game devs cant even code at all, they are all copy and paste coders cryptic has hired some cheap coders of a third world country and they just c&p code from neverwinter another pwe game. now they have added a new and very, very, very expensive crafting system and it takes you almost 7 years to reach the endlevel in crafting and if you want to speed up crafting to reach level 20 asap you would need to buy enough dilithium for 8500 dollars!!!, but you cant craft gear with the mods you want, instead its more like a lottery crafting with random mods, its useless in this stadium. so forget it, you cant equip your toons with your own crafted gear. after that they have added a new very, very, very expensive upgrade system, this is the most expensive and overpriced system i have ever seen or heard of. you can easily burn 300 dollars away just to upgrade one shipgear loadout(6-8 weapons, 1 deflector, 1 engine, 1 shield, 1 warpcore) and it takes ages to go through all the little upgrade steps(for 1 shield i have needed over an hour to upgrade) and you have to click like a trillion times and you need tons over tons of upgrade commodities(you cant even get more some of the needed commodities anywhere in the game, they are very, very, very rare and therefore very, very, very expensive). the upgrade system is the total scam. and again this new upgrade system doesnt give you the needed mods you want, its again another lottery-like upgrade system. just to have 8 identical beams with the same mods you would need atleast 8 beams x 8 different mods - 8 = 56 trys with the upgrade system, just to get 8 identical beams with the same identical mods like crtdx4 LOL!!! and this whole process will cost you hundreds of dollars in real life money. now imagine you have to upgrade the warpcore, engine, deflector, shield of your ship and now even imagine you have 50 ships all with different gear. this will cost you thousands of dollar just to upgrade all your old stuff that you have already aquired and paid with real money. they let you pay again and again and again your stuff that you have already bought. sto is not worth the insane high costs, its maybe worth 10 bucks per month at all. you could fill a 1tb drive full with games for the money sto wants from you. i had a little trick i have used to avoid the insane high costs in form of real money. i had in the end 27 chars and 20 alts all level 50 that i have used to farm ec, dilithium, commodities, contraband and i was a heavy multibox user. because of this little trick i could aquire everything in the game, i had everything and all ships you could get. this means i have started sometimes up to 10 game clients and i was logged in with 10 different accounts at once. i did cycle though all 47 chars to get all the doffjobs done on all of my chars. i mainly used the refugee, prisoner, officer doff exchange assignments to get more very rare and rare doffs and sell them on the exchange. all i did was switch between the game windows and do doff assignments for doffs, contraband and commodities or i did path to 2409 or did mine dilithium with my 47 chars or did the cristalline entity event and idled with 10 chars at the startpoint lol. sometimes i have played more than 18 hours per weekend day! i made trillions of ec and millions of dilithium(trade 5 contraband for 2000 dil ore every 4 hours with my 20 alts chars plus 1 main char). i did not pay a dime for the new greed rising extension, i have farmed over 2,5 million dilithium and traded it for zen and bought the dr pack ingame for 12,5k zen. i was very dissapointed by the delta rising pack, the new t6 ship are ugly beyond imagination, the stats of the ships are horrible, everything is broken in delta rising nothing works. i couldnt even login more due to crashes and server timeout and game freezes every few minutes. sto has no beta testers, we the endgame customers are the alpha and beta testers. i said to myself enough is enough, screw that. i have deinstalled sto and sold my main account. i will never again play a mmo or sto. i bought now battlefield 4 with premium and all unlocks. now i play maybe every 2 or 3 days bf4 for 2 or 3 hours per day. i only play bf4 if i really have the time and nothing else to do. i have also no monthly followup costs like in sto. i bought bf4 once and have never again to pay anything and bf4 is now 99% gameplay and fun and only 1% grinding and for the first time in 3 years i have seen a real working game support, thanks for that. now after my horrible sto experience my whole life has changed to a very good life, i have now more sleep, more energy, more money, more time, more friends, more sun, more of everything, im so glad i stopped playing sto.

reviewText: This game causes a lot of nostalgia and excitement to see what the Star Trek universe can do. reviewText: I have played this game since beta and have a Lifetime Membership, I just don't use steam to play I launch using the Star Trek Online Client.  So I probably have a couple weeks worth of actual game play time.\n\nI used to like this game and I will always be a Star Trek fan but as much as I wanted this game to suceed it has always fell short.  One it's left many promises unfulfilled even after years and the fans asking again and again doesn't matter.  What made the game good was it's stories which made me feel like I was in a interactive Star Trek episode but they have now all but stopped the featured episodes in favor of these large exploration zones, that would be alright if a player felt like they were accomplishing something but for example the Dyson Sphere your given a general objective clear out the enemies you do that and the enemies just keep respawning beind you in the same place making it feel like you're accomplishing nothing, no sense of progression.  There is no real attachment to your crew or ship, this is one of the unfullfilled promises from the developers, other than the bridge variants the rest the ship is exacty the same no matter what class or size ship you are in, there is nothing really interactive or things to do inside the ship and doors and hallways are disproportationaly large making it feel off.  One of the worst things they implemented was the Doff system which makes the make feel like Facebook's Farmville where the player has to constantly log in every few hours to re-que missions to earn better equimplent and skills.  These Doff missions also require resources which require grinding of a few missions hundreds of times to det top tier, this gets boring real fast.  The game has severly suffered from lack of PVP, it's in there just there is no real point to it and it's not really fun with no real rewards to playing it.  One of the worst is Cryptic won't let you post any negative feedback on their forums about game improvement or critiques doing so will get the person a warning or banned.  There's a lot more but like I said I really wanted the game to succeed but it's just not going to happen.

reviewText:
A good free game that offers one infiniate playability at the cost of never seeing anything new. There is constant updates and new missions, but there is no startrek diplomatic or scientific missions, like those you see on the show; unless they are player built. All missions seem to be shoot them up, space lazer operas of no diplomatic possability.

You can get the biggest and best stuff simply by playing a lot, which is great, considering the market design and functions of the game are based on free-to-pay additions; new content in the form of ships, interiors, pets, species, acocunt upgrades, ect. Honestly, I love how they do things, and although the ship prices are steep, they do provide ways to have such tier 6 ships simply through investing your time and intelligence; a beautiful consideration to the general player base.

sound is amazing, and often there is voice actors from the show(s) making apperences in the new release miussion content. Space battle - although a strange auditory concept and impractical possability - are great. I love the sound of battle in this game. Likewise, the score is great. The music really makes the feel of the missions.

The graphics are great. A tad cartoonish, granted they could make this game feel a little more realistic and gritty, it still provides an adventuristic sense; like the original series innocense that keeps the game psychologically positive, and you the obvious good guy.  The worlds are well done and there seems to be a pretty good adherence to startrek universal cannon in their design. The space battles are amazing light shows. This game was graphically made to be played in the space regions and in ship-to-ship battle. Here, unlike when 'on the gorund' or as an away team"
date: there is a dark gritty feel to fighting. Space battle starts to feel merceless
recommended: with hardly any quarter asusmed for the 10 thousand ships you will destroy over your carrier in starfleet. This game also renders PC wallpaper or generally artistic screen shot of one's ship or space combat. The graphics are brilliant in this realm of the game
hoursPlayed: and over all
voteText: good througout the game as a whole.\n\nHints: go tac captin for captin abilities. Always pick an alien race for the efficiant and other space based bonuses. Save money for all "efficiant" crews and build a ship with a high priority for damage dealing. DPS is the god of this game
helpfulPercent: where cruisers with survivability to certain energy types implimented into their deisgn comes second. PVP is a buyers market
votesHelpful: where you will be crushed by those who bought better ships/gear/gold unless you are a master captin in skill and timing
votesTotal: or a cloaked oppertunist who can swoop in and kill fast.\n\nThis game is great. I will continually play it - a mission here or there over a week - for the next 4 years as I have for the last 4. 10/10 game"
