reviewText: This game, like so many, has its ups and downs.  On the list of positives, there are things like the ship designs (which are really cool), the missions you get to go on (they all feel like actual things you would do if you were in a Star Trek episode), the fact that featured episodes are voice-acted (the most recent, involving the Sphere, has the actual voice of Worf from The Next Generation), the multiplayer element of the game (incl. PvE and PvP missions both on the ground and in space), and the events they run from time to time.  On the other hand, it gets really repetitive after a while...most of the things you do in missions are in text, not in actual minigames that you can play.\n\nOne way this MMO departs from others is that the combat is not click-click-click you're dead"
date: to put it that way...you actually have to dodge the grenades the Romulans across the room throw
recommended: or set up turrets and lure Klingons into a trap.  The game also has a difficulty controller; if you think your missions are too easy
hoursPlayed: you can change to a higher difficulty for better loot and more of a challenge (seriously
voteText: enemy disruptor blasts consume a lot more shield HP in Expert than they do in Normal!).\n\nIts downfall is that it gets repetitive after a while.  Missions are usually "oh
helpfulPercent: go kill that small fleet of Reman ships" or "take an away team down to the planet and scan relics".  The crafting is also super boring; you need to collect (or purchase) a lot of items to put ship components together.\n\nThe game has a slight pay-to-play nature
votesHelpful: not nearly as bad as I've seen but still very existent.  You'll need ZEN (the microtransaction currency) to purchase some of the best ships
votesTotal: though if you collect enough Dilithium (an in-game currency that everyone is available to collect in fair quantities) you can trade it in for ZEN.  But it's going to take a lot of Dilithium to buy that Osperey Cruiser or Advanced Obelisk Carrier (the best ships cost 2500 ZEN
commentsCount: 000 Dilithium
column16: and you can only collect a few thousand per day at most
column17: even if you're subscribed).\n\nNaturally there is an element of player-formed alliances; in this game they are called Fleets
column18: and they can participate in otherwise closed battles against AI or other people
column19: but I haven't gotten there yet.  You don't need to be any particular level to join a fleet
column20: but lots of fleets will require that you reach the highest level in the game (currently lvl. 50
column21: which translates to a Federation Vice Admiral).  The community doesn't seem too bad.  Also
column22: leveling is a piece of cake.  All it usually takes is a single mission to gain a level.  Every 10 or so you get a newer
column23: larger
column24: better ship.\n\nAll in all
column25: I say give the game a shot.  You may find that its repetitiveness gets the best of you.  Or you may be taken away by the scenery as you blow other starships to bits (oh yeah

reviewText:
I've played this game for 700 hours, and have played this game to win. I've played this game to max out my level, achieve the highest score, get the most out of my characters.

Before I explain why I dont like this game,

I would recommend this game if you are looking to have a fun time, if you are a casual gamer and a star trek nerd, you should definately give this game a shot. You can play through the campaign and have fun with your friends easily without spending a dime. Anything beyond that, I am not so sure, unless you like grinding your organs to mush. So, if you are in it for fun, and not to win it, then absolutely go on and download this game, skip the rest of what I have to say.

Now, if the above does not apply to you, I would not recommend this game if you are looking to do what I did in this game, play to win. Before I start my review of the game as a whole, which might turn into a rant, let me say one major turnoff to all non-casual gamers, and that is that this game is SUPER DUPER POOPER SCOOPER Pay 2 Win, it's really pay 2 win, and every update that the devs stick into the disgrace of a game that it is right now, make it more and more pay 2 win.

Originally created in a sort of rock paper scissors manner where you needed different classes of ships and types of captains to win in pvp or pve, (which mainly become the game after the storyline, and becomes a repetitive grind anyhow), the developers are slowly getting rid of this concept. It is common knowledge among all veteran players of this game that all that matters if you really want to win, is DPS. The usefulness of players that run ships like cruisers and science ships is so miniscule compared to those of escorts (the tactical officers main ship), and high dps cruisers, a more recent addition, (disgusting imo), that at high levels, after long hours of grinding, you will find yourself obsolete as anything but an escort player or tactical officer. This problem is so large that you will find that when you enter PvP especially, that players will exploit the broken game mechanics enormously, pairing different equipments, bonuses, and abilities, (there are so damn many), in ways that they are not intended, but allowed by the developers, that they are impossible to beat. The exploitation of everything at high ranks, the balancing of statistics to get the most out of escorts and such, really retracts from the star trek atmosphere. There are so many flaws I can go on and on about in the game, and before I run out of breath talking about this one flaw, exploitation, ill just lay them all out for you:

1. Players exploit the game at high levels
2. The game is unbalanced for different playstyles at higher levels
3. Most players are at max level so you cant do anything in pvp
4. After you finish a set of missions, you will find yourself grinding the same PvE events for countless hours for just a few pieces of borg tech for example, unless you deem yourself a wallet warrior.
5. The in-game economy is very limited and boring.
6. The actual storyline is repetitive and sparse.
7. Broken game mechanics brings little variety to ships (if they want to win and be useful)
8. They are always adding new ways to spend money or grind your organs to mush, they add plenty of new ships, plenty of new equipment, and new missions to get equipment, they hardly work on REALLY fixing the game and polishing it's mechanics. Instead of revisiting problems, they will simply expand. For example, if cruisers are underpowered because tanking and drawing fire is useless in PvE, they simply increase the damage of cruisers)
9. Besides the main storyline, side missions or personal missions are just as boring and typical, almost 100% of them are just rinse and repeat. Go shoot some ships, shoot some people on the ground, and run around pressing F to do some scan sci-fi stuff.
10. Did I mention scans and the F key? Yes, everything besides shooting ♥♥♥♥ up, (which is easy because your character and ship locks onto everything automatically, making every enemy encounter just repeated buttons to press over and over, even with autofire on you are simply using your simple and boring abilities over and over to kill your enemy, waiting for abilities to recharge, rinse and repeat, rinse and repeat, grind GRIND GRIND!!!!

Sorry, went on a bit of a tangent. Anyway back to the F key. Anything besides shooting ♥♥♥♥ up is basically going around, pressing the F key, whether you are healing wounded patients or scanning asteroids, you simply press the F key and wait for the bar to reach 100% and yay thats all. This isn't completely true, there are a few things in the campaign and side missions and stuff in the game that require a bit of skill, but 90% of these tasks have the same mechanics, and the way they are set up (easy as hell and boring to tears), you can probably set up a couple of macros to solve them anyway if you really cared. There are only a few instances in the newer campaigns that aren't the same damn easy puzzle, repeated over and over. The only useful mini-game is the one that you use to go dilithium mining, and that one is... Ok. :)

Back on course, I think the #1 problem is the broken mechanics at higher levels:

You will encounter players using dyson ships (completely STO-unique ships), firing romulan weapons (disruptors), using only beam weapons, (because multi-weapon ships are useless besides the occasional special weapon, and torpedoes are largely useless too thank you game mechanics), using borg ship modules, while using tholian engines and shields.

Now this above issue isn't just an isolated thing, like you will see one in a handful of people doing this. Absolutely not, unless you are a low level player that doesn't know what he is doing, when you achieve higher ranks of Admiral, which everyone does pretty quickly, you will find that everyone is forced to do completely uncharacteristic things. You will find starfleet ships using antiproton weapons, and only antiproton cannons, or only antiproton beams, because adding a torpedo to a weapons slot would be useless, as torpedoes are quite useless without wasting plenty of skill points on them anyway and you need those skill points for beam weapons becuase torpedoes do nothing against enemy shields. (I could go farther but that would probably bore you)

The worst thing that ever happened to this game was Perfect World Entertainment acquiring it from the original creators, Cryptic Studios. From the stories told by my clan mates, who have played this game from the creation, the game was a lot better, focused a lot less on giveusmoneygiveusmoneygiveusmoneygiveusmoney with PWE.

I quit it a bit ago after getting fed up with all of the ♥♥♥♥ updates that were just excuses for PWE to make more money.

reviewText:
Updated Aug, 2015:

Community is a horrible cesspool and the devs run the game into the ground through a horrible pay for advantage scheme that is a mixture of insanely grindy time gates and ships that can cost upwards of $30 each, and there are limited time lockbox and event ships that go for even more in the market.

I've heard stories of people dropping $200 on a single ship.

To make matters worse all end game gear is gated with a huge in game currency price premium.

Some people in this game have 15+ Alts who do nothing but grind all day and stroke their ego. Very grindy =( especially with Gear that has so much RNG attached to it.

- PVP is abvandoned. You need to invest hundreds of dollars to PVP.
- PVE is a DPS race. You need to invest a lot of time to grind out gear for obscure game breaking exploits.
- Ground combat was abandoned. I like it more than space, but I am a huge minority.
- NOBODY does stuff via the LFG queue.
- The Story is really, really ♥♥♥♥ing good.

reviewText: This game causes a lot of nostalgia and excitement to see what the Star Trek universe can do. But this game is riddled with bugs, glitches, display problems, choppy fps drops, and hilarious lag issues. If cryptic can stop sucking up the players' money for a month or so and genuinely patch the game, this may improve. PvE events are non-existent, the grind is still horrible. The tutorial sticks you with skills and abilities you may not want and doesnt even let you respecialize to your own liking. You have to buy a token which you can obtain without spending actual money, but it'll take weeks of grinding for Dilithium Crystals just to afford it. My overall rating on this bug-ridden distaster is a 2 out of 5. It seems Cryptic has lost its sense of gaming and just dove for the players' wallets. Patches are meant to improve the game, new content is supposed to add new things.. but clearly its just layering on more time wasted grinding away for a ship or loadout you can't do without paying actual money.

reviewText:
I love Star Trek. I always have, and I'm pretty sure I always will. I loved this game for a long time, too.

What I'm not a fan of, is the way things on this have turned recently within STO.

The atmosphere of the game is wrong. When I first started playing, it was a happy, very lore-friendly place filed with lots of people trying to get their way into the TV screen we all watched our first episodes on. Recently, the lay of the land has become confusing. To say you have to grind a lot is the understatement of the milenium. EVERYTHING is a grind now, unless you want to pay for it. It has also become increasingly apparent that PWE is searching for money: In-game purchases are fine, but when you give us 3 new ships and 10 new costumes every other week, it gets ridiculous.

I think one of the things I have been experiencing serves as a perfect explination. The game only launches on safe mode. In the time that this bug began to now, I count at least 19 new ships that have been added to the game (not including fleet model ships).

The new way of grinding is... well, bad. Horrendous. An abomination. A lot of the new grinds require vast sums of dilithium, which is hard to farm for, and is quantity capped at 8000 units a day, which is a penny in the well of what you'll actually need. Now, dilitium is hard to farm for, but guess what PWE sells. Zen. Guess what you can by dilithium for, kiddies. Zen.

All in all, this game is very good. I wouldn't have spent so much time on it otherwise, but I'm terrified that this will turn into Guitar Hero. A good game, a great idea, but driven into the ground harder than a Mack truck hitting a freight train because they produced too much new content too fast, and people got sick of it.

Also: when you advertise an upgrade to your existing tier 5 ships to make them tier 5u" ships
date: make them equal to the tier 6 ships. The imbalance is ridiculous. I have top-tier gear on my odyssey (including your $5 upgrade). It can't keep pace with anything on tier 6
recommended:
and thats not okay.

To Perfect World Entertainment:

Fix your mistakes before you turn into another guitar hero rerun."

reviewText:
While many people critiques this game for being buggy and the constant need to pay to progress well I find it quite a good MMO for a massive Star Trek fan.

The game itself does have some bugs or mission breaking problems but you can restart all missions and generally it works the 2nd time, also regarding pay to progress yes when you reach Max level you need to pay $$$ to get a good ship and gear or if you have time you can earn Dilithiam (one of the ingame currencies) that you can sell for Zen (The real money currency)

I have played well over 400 hours so far (And 100 since I moved to playing this on steam) and I have spent about $40 of real money on it, that money was used to but extra character slots to create a few Alts to do Missions to get extra Dilithium.

Pro's:
* Very Good story missions
* The new Delta recruit system rewards you for making new characters
* Voices from various Star Trek actors
* Totally free to play if you have the patience
* Pick up and play if you have an hour to kill you can hop in have a go at a few events and log off
* Great graphics for an older game that will run on most systems
* Event - New events are added all the time
* Constant update: New missions are added all the time
* Loads of classic Star Trek areas to explore

Cons:
* OK Bugs some missions are bugged which you can bypass
* Bridge Officers (Power) have a tenancy to reset if you switch ships which means you need to reset them
* A few features that seems to be there but abandoned (Gold pressed latinum store) would be nice to have expanded or at least updated
* Queues for some PVP and PVE events can take to long due to lack of people not max level participating (XP rewards boost needed)

So all in all it is worth getting and giving this game a go if you like star trek at all
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Star Trek Online: An MMO RPG where you begin as a captain of a 'Miranda-Class', 'ShiKahr-Class' or 'Centaur-Class' Light Cruiser of the Federation. Travel across the Alpha, Beta, Gamma and Delta quadrants of the Milky Way Galxy, fighting numerous opponents such as Klingons, Romulans, Cardassians and many many more. Pilot your ship in ever-challenging combat scenarios and send yourself along with an away team to different planets to fight intense ground combat battles. You will ascend through the ranks of the Federation and gain new and more powerful ships along the way, choosing either a Science, Engineering or Tactical path as you become one of the most powerful captains the Federation has ever seen.


So I have around about 45 or so hours on this game on steam, around the same amount off of it also, and let me tell you it's my favourite game outright on PC. It's one of those games where it's so rich in lore and exciting combat, I can hardly get off of it. The story has clearly been designed by people passionate about all Star Trek lore, including the newer J.J. Abrams movies, as you'll see in the story. The episodes you play are exciting, clever and challenging, so much so that I find myself engulfed in a battle against a huge Romulan D'Deridex warbird in my reasonably large Intrepid Long-Range Science Vessel.

The combat GUI and controls are very nicely assigned allowing fluid and immersive combat on ground and exhilarating space combat, paired with gorgeous 3D visuals and beautiful particle effects it fully immerses you into the Star Trek galaxy. This game is beautifully designed by a great team; Cryptic have successfully made a game woprthy of being canon with the Star Trek Universe.

So I should do a traditional Pros V Cons" list so here goes.

Pros:
~ Great Servers
date: never experienced any lag and loading times for large areas are decent.\n~ Nice Selection of Ships
recommended: huge lists of small shuttles all the way to the monstrous "Obelisk Carrier"... it's big.\n~ Great Story Missions
hoursPlayed: facing a huge selection of enemies from all the Star Trek TV and Movies.\n~ Beautiful Visuals
voteText: maps and particle effects are great
helpfulPercent: along with the ships too.\n~ Lovely community
votesHelpful: never seen any kind of hate war on the chat
votesTotal: only people willing to trade and help eachother out.\n~ Combat difficulty is dependent on your level
votesFunny: not the mission order.\n~ Custom Player
commentsCount: Bridge Officers
column16: Ship
column17: Ship Name AND Ship Designation Number (NCC-1701 style)\n~ EPIC MUSIC
column18:
nuff said.

Cons:
~ Pay to play is evidently the case for higher level players wanting more ships or ships of better quality.
~ Some ground tasks within missions can seem more like a fool's errand more than "Investigating" however of course that sometimes is the life of a starfleet officer.
~ Patch download the first time is quite substantial and is always increasing with every update.
~ Really Nitpicking
column19:
the planet's aren't full scale.


All together I completely recommend this genious brilliant game
